7 
8 
9 
 
10 
App. A to Def.โs Resp. (docket no. 74 at 44).5   
11 
Hunters Property Holdings, LLC (14), The Richmark Company d/b/a Richmark 
12 
Label (10), Wade Biller (12), 12th and Pike Associates LLC (4), and Olive Street 
13 
Apartments LLC (6) seek to represent the Property Owners Subclass.  Mot. (docket 
14 
15   
16  5 As of the date of this Order, plaintiffs Argento LLC (1), see docket no. 59, and Northwest Liquor and 
Wine LLC (5), see docket no. 71, have voluntarily dismissed their claims against the City.  Although 
17  Madrona Real Estate Services LLC (24) is physically located outside of the proposed Class Area, it is a 
member of the putative class because it manages a building within the area.  See Ex. 3 to Weaver Decl. 
(docket no. 66-1) (explaining that Madrona Real Estate Services LLC manages a building at 12th Avenue 
18 
and East Pike Street).  At oral argument, Plaintiffs conceded that Greenus Building, Inc. (20), Madrona 
Real Estate Investors IV LLC (23), and Madrona Real Estate Investors VI LLC (22) are not members of 
19  the putative class because these entities are located outside of the proposed Class Area.  See also Pls.โ 
Resp. to Def.โs 2d Interrogs. No. 9, Ex. 82 to Farmer Decl. (docket no. 75-82).  Hunters Capital, LLC (2, 
20  3, 14, 15, 19, 20 & 21) and Redside Partners LLC (9, 16 & 25) are members of the putative class because 
they own and/or manage properties within the Class Area.  See Ex. 3 to Weaver Decl.  Nevertheless, they 
also seek damages for three properties located outside of the area, specifically, the Dunn Motors Building 
21 
(19), the Colman Building (21), and a building at 1323 East Pine Street (25).  See Pls.โ Resp. to Def.โs 2d 
Interrogs. No. 9.  Plaintiffs have requested that the claims associated with these properties proceed 
22  alongside the claims of the putative class, if certified. 
23 
ORDER - 7 
 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 96   Filed 05/09/22   Page 8 of 37
 
 
 
1  no. 65 at 21).  SRJ Enterprises d/b/a Car Tender (18), Bergmanโs Lock and Key Services 
2  LLC (13), Shuffle LLC d/b/a Cure Cocktail (17), and Sway and Cake LLC (11) seek to 
3  represent the Business Owners Subclass.  Id.  Finally, Matthew Ploszaj (8) seeks to 
4  represent the Residents Subclass.6  Id.  
5  Discussion 
6  1.  Standard for Class Certification 
7  Rule 23 operates as โan exception to the usual rule that litigation is conducted by 
8  and on behalf of the individual named parties only.โ  Comcast Corp. v. Behrend, 569 
9  U.S. 27, 33 (2013) (quoting Califano v. Yamasaki, 442 U.S. 682, 700โ01 (1979)).  To 
10  maintain a class action, a plaintiff must โaffirmatively demonstrateโ compliance with 
11  Rule 23.  Id. (quoting Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. Dukes, 564 U.S. 338, 350 (2011)).  The 
12  prerequisites of Rule 23 are not mere pleading standards, but rather are evidentiary 
13  thresholds.  See Wal-Mart, 564 U.S. at 350.  โEven if the common questions do not 
14  predominate over the individual questions so that class certification of the entire action is 
15  warranted, Rule 23 authorizes the district court in appropriate cases to isolate the 
16  common issues under [Rule 23(c)(4)] and proceed with class treatment of these particular 
17  issues.โ  Valentino, 97 F.3d at 1234.  The Ninth Circuitโs approval of issues classes under 
18  Rule 23(c)(4) does not obviate the need to meet the requirements of Rules 23(a) and (b).  
19 
 
20 
6 Hunters Capital, LLC (2, 3, 14, 15, 19, 20 & 21), Onyx Homeowners Association (7), Madrona Real 
21 
Estate Services LLC (24), and Redside Partners LLC (9, 16 & 25) request appointment only as 
representatives of the main class.  Mot. (docket no. 65 at 20).  These plaintiffs do not seek to represent 
22  any of the three proposed subclasses.  See Ex. 3 to Weaver Decl. (docket no. 66-1). 
23 
ORDER - 8 
 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 96   Filed 05/09/22   Page 9 of 37
 
 
 
1  See Amador v. Baca, No. 10-cv-01649, 2016 WL 6804910, at *3 (C.D. Cal. July 27, 
2  2016).  Plaintiffs bear the burden, by a preponderance of the evidence, see Olean 
3  Wholesale Grocery Coop., Inc. v. Bumble Bee Foods LLC, No. 19-56514, 2022 WL 
4  1053459, at *5 (9th Cir. Apr. 8, 2022), to prove that there are questions of law or fact 
5  common to class members that โwill resolve an issue that is central to the validity of each 
6  one of the claims in one stroke,โ see Walmart, 564 U.S. at 350. 
7  Here, Plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that all four criteria of Rule 23(a) are 
8  satisfied, namely that:  (i) the class is so numerous that joinder of all members is 
9  impracticable; (ii) questions of law or fact common to the class exist; (iii) Plaintiffsโ 
10  claims are typical of the claims of the class; and (iv) Plaintiffs will fairly and adequately 
11  protect the interests of the class, see Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a).  If all Rule 23(a) criteria are 
12  met, Plaintiffs must also establish that the proposed class qualifies under at least one of 
13  the three provisions of Rule 23(b).  See Comcast, 569 U.S. at 33.  With these standards in 
14  mind, the Court turns to the requirements of Rule 23(a). 
15  2.  Rule 23(a) Requirements 
16  a.  Numerosity 
17  Plaintiffs estimate that the Class Area contains at least 4,500 to 5,000 putative 
18  class members, comprised of approximately 4,000 residents, 300 businesses, and 600 
19  property owners.  Weaver Decl. at ยถ 2 (docket no. 66); see also Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(1) 
20  (requiring that a proposed class be โso numerous that joinder of all members is 
21  impracticableโ).  The City appears to concede that Rule 23(a)(1)โs numerosity 
22 
23 
ORDER - 9 
 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 96   Filed 05/09/22   Page 10 of 37
 
 
 
1  requirement is satisfied in this case.7  Accordingly, the Court concludes that the proposed 
2  class is sufficiently numerous.   
3  b.  Commonality 
4  To satisfy Rule 23(a)(2)โs commonality requirement, Plaintiffs must demonstrate 
5  that the claims of all potential class members depend on a common question of such 
6  nature as โis capable of classwide resolution.โ  Olean, 2022 WL 1053459, at *4 (quoting 
7  Wal-Mart, 564 U.S. at 350).  The test is whether the determination of the truth or falsity 
8  of the common question โwill resolve an issue that is central to the validity of each one of 
9  the claims in one stroke.โ  Id. at *4 (quoting Wal-Mart, 564 U.S. at 350).  As the 
10  Supreme Court has explained: 
11  What  matters . . . is  not  the  raising  of  common  โquestionsโโeven  in 
drovesโbut, rather the capacity of a class-wide proceeding to generate 
12  common answers apt to drive the resolution of the litigation.  Dissimilarities 
within  the  proposed  class  are  what  have  the  potential  to  impede  the 
13  generation of common answers. 
 
14  Wal-Mart, 564 U.S. at 350 (emphasis in original, quoting Richard A. Nagareda, Class 
15  Certification in the Age of Aggregate Proof, 84 N.Y.U. L. REV. 97, 132 (2009)).  In 
16  contrast, an individual question is one where putative class members must present 
17  evidence that varies from member to member.  Olean, 2022 WL 1053459, at *4 (citing 
18  Tyson Foods, Inc. v. Bouaphakeo, 577 U.S. 442, 453 (2016)).   
19  The City argues that dissimilarities within the proposed class frustrate common 
20  answers to the particular issues Plaintiffs seek to certify under Rule 23(c)(4).  To prove 
21 
 
22  7 The City does not address numerosity in its response to Plaintiffsโ motion. 
23 
ORDER - 10 
 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 96   Filed 05/09/22   Page 11 of 37
 
 
 
1  the issues are common questions of law or fact central to the validity of their claims, 
2  Plaintiffs must establish that the proposed issues โare capable of being established 
3  through a common body of evidence, applicable to the whole class.โ  See id. at *6.  The 
4  Court must engage in a โrigorous assessmentโ of the available evidence and the method 
5  by which Plaintiffs intend to prove the common questions in one stroke.  See id. at *7 
6  (citation omitted).  The Courtโs inquiry will necessarily โentail some overlap with the 
7  meritsโ of the underlying claims because class certification considerations are generally 
8  โenmeshedโ in the factual and legal issues associated with the causes of action being 
9  pursued.  See Wal-Mart, 564 U.S. at 351; see also Comcast, 569 U.S. at 33โ34.  The 
10  Court must, therefore, examine the elements of Plaintiffsโ claims and the particular issues 
11  for which class certification is sought.  
12  i.  Procedural Due Process

1  To establish a substantive due process claim a plaintiff must show:  
2  (i) governmental deprivation of life, liberty, or property; and (ii) โconscience shocking 
3  behavior by the government.โ  Brittain v. Hansen, 451 F.3d 982, 991 (9th Cir. 2006).  
4  โThe Due Process Clause is a limitation on state action and is not a โguarantee of certain 
5  minimal levels of safety and security.โโ  Martinez v. City of Clovis, 943 F.3d 1260, 1271 
6  (9th Cir. 2019) (quoting DeShaney v. Winnebago Cnty. Depโt of Soc. Servs., 489 U.S. 
7  189, 195 (1989)).  Because โthe Fourteenth Amendmentโs Due Process Clause generally 
8  does not confer any affirmative right to governmental aid, even where such aid may be 
9  necessary to secure life, liberty, or property interests,โ government actors are usually not 
10  required to protect individuals from third parties.  Patel v. Kent Sch. Dist., 648 F.3d 965, 
11  968 (9th Cir. 2011).  The Ninth Circuit has recognized two exceptions to this general 
12  rule:  (i) โa special relationship between the plaintiff and the state may give rise to a 
13  constitutional duty to protect,โ and (ii) a duty to protect may arise from a state-created 
14  danger.  Martinez, 943 F.3d at 1271โ72.  Only the state-created danger exception is at 
15  issue in this case.10 
16  Under the state-created danger exception, a state may violate substantive due 
17  process if it โโaffirmatively places [a plaintiff] . . . in danger by acting with โdeliberate 
18  indifferenceโ to a โknown or obvious danger.โโ  Martinez, 943 F.3d at 1271 (quoting 
19  Patel, 648 F.3d at 971โ72).  This exception requires proof that:  (i) an officerโs

9  iii.  Takings 
 
10  Plaintiffsโ third cause of action alleges a violation of the Fifth Amendmentโs 
11  Takings Clause, TAC at ยถยถ 203โ08, which applies to local governments through the 
12  Fourteenth Amendment.  Webbโs Fabulous Pharmacies, Inc. v. Beckwith, 449 U.S. 155, 
13  160 (1980).  The Fifth Amendment provides:  โnor shall private property be taken for 
14  public use, without just compensation.โ  U.S. Const. amend. V.  When the government 
15  physically acquires private property for public use, a โphysical takingโ has occurred.  
16  Cedar Point Nursery v. Hassid, 141 S. Ct. 2063, 2071 (2021).  If the government imposes 
17  regulations that restrict a landownerโs use of his or her own property, it might commit a 
18  โregulatory taking.โ  Id. at 2072.  A temporary interference with the use of property can 
19  be considered a regulatory taking.  Penn Cent. Transp. Co. v. New York City, 438 U.S. 
20  104, 124 (1978); see also Bridge Aina Leโa, LLC v. Land Use Commโn, 950 F.3d 610, 
21  626 (9th Cir. 2020).  Whether a regulation amounts to a regulatory taking requires a court 
22  to engage in โad hoc, factual inquiries.โ  See Penn Cent., 438 U.S. at 124 (explaining that 
23

2  extent to which the regulation has interfered with a plaintiffโs investment-backed 
3  expectations).   
4  Washington and federal courts โare reluctant to find that a compensable taking 
5  occurred where the government temporarily used or destroyed property in times of 
6  emergency.โ  Citoli v. City of Seattle, 115 Wn. App. 459, 489, 61 P.3d 1165 (2002) 
7  (citing Natโl Bd. of Young Menโs Christian Assโns (YMCA) v. United States, 395 U.S. 85, 
8  92โ93 (1969)).  Where the โnecessitiesโ of civil disturbance require injury to private 
9  property, โthe resulting losses must be borne by the owners of the property.โ  Id.  Action 
10  taken for the purpose of, and reasonably necessary to, public safety does not generally 
11  give rise to a compensable taking.  Id. at 491 (โCitoli effectively asks us to substitute 
12  either his judgment or our judgment for that of trained police officers on the best way to

19  knowledge.  Thus, the failure-to-enforce exception cannot be applied on a class-wide 
20  basis in this action.

5  c.  Typicality 
6  Rule 23(a)(3) requires that a plaintiffโs claims or defenses be โtypical of the claims 
7  or defenses of the class.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(3).  โThe purpose of the typicality 
8  requirement is to assure that the interest of the named representative aligns with the 
9  interests of the class.โ  Hanon v. Dataproducts Corp., 976 F.2d 497, 508 (9th Cir. 1992).  
10  โThe test of typicality โis whether other members have the same or similar injury, 
11  whether the action is based on conduct which is not unique to the named plaintiffs, and 
12  whether other class members have been injured by the same course of conduct.โโ  Ellis v. 
13  Costco Wholesale Corp., 657 F.3d 970, 984 (9th Cir. 2011) (quoting Hanon, 976 F.2d at 
14  508).  โTypicality refers to the nature of the claim or defense . . . not to the specific facts 
15  from which it arose or the relief sought.โ  Id. 
16  The City does not argue that Plaintiffsโ claims or defenses are atypical of the 
17  claims or defenses of putative class.  Instead, the City contends that Plaintiffs have failed 
18  to establish typicality because they have not shown that putative class members suffered 
19  the same or similar injury as Plaintiffs, or any injury at all.  โWhere some of the class

14 
Rule 23(b)(3) requires that a class action be โsuperior to other available methods 
15 
for fairly and efficiently adjudicating the controversy.โ  โA class action is the superior 
16

17 
1234โ35.  A class action is not the superior method in this case because individualized 
18 
factual issues make it difficult to manage a class and undesirable to concentrate the 
19 
litigation of all claims in one forum.  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3)(C) & (D).

21 
claims or the claims of individuals and entities located inside or outside the Class Area.

8  and file a Joint Status Report proposing methods for case management in this action.  The 
9  parties should explore the possible trial of three or four representative plaintiffs (to be 
10  selected by the parties and/or the Court), or other ways to address the complex nature of 
11  this action given the variety and number of named plaintiffs.  The parties should also 
12  address whether amendment to the case schedule and trial date will be necessary.  See 
13  Order (docket no. 46).  The Court will schedule a status conference to address case 
14  management after it reviews the partiesโ Joint Status Report. 
15  (3)  The Clerk is directed to send a copy of this Order to all counsel of record. 
16  IT IS SO ORDERED. 
17  Dated this 9th day of May, 2022. 
A
18 
19  Thomas S. Zilly 
United States District Judge

23    ORDER: Defendant's 11  motion to dismiss the fourth cause of 
action based on equal protection is GRANTED. This claim is 
dismissed without prejudice. Plaintiffs may electronically file a 
second amended complaint via the Case Management and 
Electronic Case Filing ("CM/ECF") system within fourteen (14) 
days of the date of this Order. Except as provided in paragraph (1), 
the motion to dismiss all other causes of action is DENIED. The 
motion to deny class certification is DENIED without prejudice 
pending discovery for the reasons stated in this Order. The motion 
to stay discovery, docket no. 16  , is now DENIED as moot. 
Signed by Judge Thomas S. Zilly.(MW) (Entered: 10/16/2020) 
10/22/2020  MINUTE ORDER: Having reviewed the parties' Joint Status 
24   
Report, docket no. 21  , indicating that the City requests that 
the Court convene a scheduling conference before entering a 
scheduling order, the Court now SETS a telephone conference call 
for Thursday, October 29, 2020, at 10:30 a.m. The Court's staff will 
be in contact with counsel to provide a conference call number and 
access code. Authorized by Judge Thomas S. Zilly. (MW) (Entered: 
10/22/2020) 
10/29/2020  25   MINUTE ENTRY for proceedings held before Hon. Judge Thomas 
S. Zilly- Dep Clerk: Gail Glass; Pla Counsel: Angelo Calfo, Patty 
Eakes and Tyler Weaver; Def Counsel: Tyler Farmer, Joseph 
Groshong, Art Harringan and Kristin Ballinger; CR: NONE; Time 
of Hearing: 10:30 a.m.; Telephone Conference held on 
10/29/2020. Counsel appear telephonically. The Court and counsel 
discuss the Joint Status Report, docket no. 21  . For the reasons 
discussed at the conference, the Court GRANTS Plaintiffs' request 
to file an amended complaint to add state law claims. The parties 
agree that a discovery conference and the phasing of discovery is no 
longer necessary. The Court DIRECTS that the parties participate in 
the alternative dispute resolution program after discovery is 
completed pursuant to LCR 39.1. The jury trial is SET to 
commence on Monday, June 6, 2022. A scheduling order will be 
entered to reflect the dates discussed at the telephone conference. -
Adjourned.(GG) (Entered: 10/29/2020)

  Plaintiffs,

  v.

CITY OF SEATTLE,

      Defendant. 
22 
23 
  ORDER - 1 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 23   Filed 10/16/20   Page 2 of 30
 
 
 
1   
THIS MATTER comes before the Court on the City of Seattleโs (โCityโ) Motion 
2 
to Dismiss and Deny Class Certification (โMotionโ), docket no. 11, and its Motion for a 
3 
Stay of Discovery, docket no. 16.  Having reviewed all papers filed in support of, and in 
4 
opposition to, the motions, the Court enters the following Order. 
5 
Background 
6 
  On June 8, 2020, with nationwide civil rights protests ongoing, the City โabruptly 
7 
desertedโ the Seattle Police Departmentโs (โSPDโ) East Precinct, located on the corner of 
8 
Twelfth Avenue and East Pine Street in Seattleโs Capitol Hill neighborhood.  First 
9 
Amended Class Action Complaint (โFACโ) at ยถ 3 (docket no. 9).  Almost immediately 
10 
after the SPD abandoned the East Precinct, protestors declared the area โFree Capitol 
11 
Hillโ to create a โno-copโ zone, and they used large barriers that the City left behind to 
12 
block off streets within one block of the precinct.  Id. at ยถยถ 36โ38.  As the zone expanded, 
13 
it first became known as the โCapitol Hill Autonomous Zone,โ a.k.a. โCHAZ,โ and 
14 
eventually became known as the โCapitol Hill Organized Protestโ or โCapitol Hill 
15 
Occupying Protest,โ a.k.a. โCHOPโ (collectively, โCHOPโ).  Id. at ยถยถ 1, 38.  CHOPโs 
16 
unofficial boundaries stretched north to East Denny Way, east to Thirteenth Avenue, 
17 
south to East Pike Street, and west to Broadway Avenue, encompassing Cal Anderson 
18 
Park and 16 city blocks in all.  Id. at ยถ 39.  
19 
  CHOP participants claimed the area as their own, which was allegedly governed 
20 
by a โloose form of governance and justiceโ and which they secured by physically 
21 
barricading and patrolling the areaโs borders.  Id. at ยถยถ 40โ41.  Many CHOP participants 
22 
23 
  ORDER - 2 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 23   Filed 10/16/20   Page 3 of 30
 
 
 
1  set up tents and started living on the streets, sidewalks, and in Cal Anderson Park.  Id. at 
2  ยถ 42.  They allegedly occupied the streets and sidewalks 24 hours per day, hosting 
3  speeches, debates, movies, music, and even illegal fireworks shows, causing disturbances 
4  and noise pollution well past 10 p.m., and usually into the early hours of the next day.  Id. 
5  at ยถ 47.  Certain CHOP participants served as a โreplacement police forceโ by demanding 
6  that business owners release individuals suspected of crimes and conducting their own 
7  crime investigations.  Id. at ยถ 46.  Some CHOP participants were observed carrying guns 
8  in broad daylight.  Id. at ยถ 48. 
9    According to Plaintiffs, the City โentirely handed overโ the approximately 7-acre 
10  Cal Anderson Park to the CHOP participants.  Id. at ยถ 49.  The City also allegedly 
11  provided CHOP participants with medical equipment, washing/sanitation facilities, 
12  portable toilets, nighttime lighting, and other material support.  Id. at ยถยถ 49, 179โ180.  
13  The City further allowed CHOP participants to build makeshift gardens in the park โto 
14  grow food for CHOP,โ id. at ยถ 52, with the Mayor tweeting her support for the โnew 
15  community garden popping up in Cal Anderson Park,โ id. at ยถ 182(g).  Plaintiffs allege 
16  that members of the public could not use the park, and if they got too close, CHOP 
17  participants threatened them or their property.  Id. at ยถ 51.  Moreover, the โhundreds of 
18  CHOP participants in the park created excessive noise . . . at all hours of the day and 
19  night.โ  Id. at ยถ 53.  โTrash, feces, and other refuse built up in the park, affecting the 
20  whole area.โ  Id.  The park was allegedly one of the most violent areas of CHOP, and 
21  local residents witnessed individuals carrying firearms in the park.  Id.  As a result of the 
22 
23 
  ORDER - 3 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 23   Filed 10/16/20   Page 4 of 30
 
 
 
1  Cityโs alleged actions, the park โwas transformed into a massive tent city for CHOP 
2  participants,โ id. at ยถ 50, as shown below: 
3 
4 
5 
6 
7 
8 
 
9 
  [Photos provided at FAC at ยถ 51] 
10 
  On June 11, Mayor Jenny Durkan tweeted that CHOP โis not a lawless wasteland 
11 
of anarchist insurrectionโit is a peaceful expression of our communityโs collective grief 
12 
and their desire to build a better world.โ  Id. at ยถ 182(a).  That same day, during a joint 
13 
press conference with SPD Chief of Police Carmen Best, the Mayor reiterated that area 
14 
โis not an armed ANTIFA militia no-go zoneโ and that โblocks of Seattle in Capitol Hill 
15 
[have] shut down every summer for everything from Block Party to Pride.โ  Id. at 
16 
ยถ 182(d).  The Mayor also stated that the area โis not really that much of an operational 
17 
challenge[,] [b]ut we want to make sure that the businesses and residents feel safe and 
18 
weโll continue to move that forward.โ  Id.  At the time, โthe City communicated clearly to 
19 
CHOP participants that they may continue occupying the area . . . because [the City is] 
20 
trying to do things that are responsible.โ  Id. at ยถ 181.  For her part, the Police Chief 
21 
stated that โSPD has a responsibility to provide public safety services to the entire East 
22 
23 
  ORDER - 4 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 23   Filed 10/16/20   Page 5 of 30
 
 
 
1  precinct and the Cityโ and that the โactions of a small group cannot and should not 
2  deprive an entire segment of our community from public-safety services.โ  Id. at ยถ 57.  
3  The Police Chief also stated that โ[i]n the first day of the SPD not having access to the 
4  [East] precinct, response times for crimes in progress were over fifteen minutes, about 
5  three times as long as the average.โ  Id.  The Police Chief said that โ[t]he difference in the 
6  amount of time could protect someoneโs life and prevent a violent attack.โ  Id. 
7    The next day, on June 12, the Mayor was asked during a CNN interview โhow 
8  long the City would allow CHOP participants to continue,โ and the Mayor responded: โI 
9  donโt know.  We could have the Summer of Love.โ  Id. at ยถ 181(b).  She again stated that 
10  CHOP โis more like a block party atmosphereโ and that โwe will make sure that we can 
11  restore this[,]โ [b]ut we have block parties and the like in this part of Seattle all the time.  
12  Itโs known for that.โ  Id. at ยถ 182(f). 
13    On June 16, the City allegedly โreached an informal agreementโ with CHOP 
14  participants to allow limited one-way access on certain streets within the area.  Id. at 
15  ยถ 177.  As part of that agreement, Plaintiffs allege that โthe City actually fortified the rest 
16  of CHOPโ by providing participants with sturdier concrete barriers.  Id. at ยถยถ 174(d), 177. 
17  Although CHOP participants allegedly reestablished impediments on those limited-access 
18  streets, the Cityโs response was โapparently to do nothing.โ  Id. at ยถ 177.  The City issued 
19  a press release that day stating that โCity officials have been on site on Capitol Hill to 
20  work [to] meet community needs including hygiene, sanitation and safety,โ and that they 
21  had met with CHOP โorganizers, small businesses, and residents to discuss proposed 
22  changes to the protest zone.โ  Id. at ยถ 174(b).  That day, the Mayor also suggested that the 
23 
  ORDER - 5 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 23   Filed 10/16/20   Page 6 of 30
 
 
 
1  City agreed to deploy police to CHOP only for โsignificant life-safety issues,โ such as 
2  โan active shooter incident, an assault, a structure fire, significant medical emergency, 
3  and other incidents that threaten a personโs life safety.โ  Id. at ยถ 181(e).1 
4    Plaintiffs allege that the City โadopted a policy supporting the CHOP occupation, 
5  acting with deliberate indifference toward those suffering harms from it.โ  Id. at ยถ 174.  
6  Plaintiffs also allege that because of the City-provided barriers that CHOP participants 
7  used in the streets and sidewalks, local residents could not use public streets, sidewalks, 
8  or other rights-of-way to enter their homes or businesses, they could not receive 
9  deliveries, and their clients were unable to visit their businesses.  Id. at ยถยถ 70โ71, 74.  
10  Plaintiffs allege that garbage and recycling services could not enter CHOP, forcing them 
11  to pile up their refuse.  Id. at ยถ 73.  In addition, Plaintiffs allege that they did not have 
12  โfull useโ of their property that was normally freely accessible, including their garages, in 
13  order to prevent vandalism to their properties.  Id. at ยถ 72.  Plaintiffs also allege that 
14  CHOP participants painted graffiti on most available surfaces in the area.  Id. at ยถ 43.  If a 
15  property owner painted over the graffiti, CHOP participants allegedly replaced the graffiti 
16  or threatened business owners if they painted over the graffiti.  Examples of the allegedly 
17  pervasive graffiti are shown below: 
18 
19 
20 
 
21 
1 The Court takes judicial notice of the full press release, see FAC at ยถยถ 181(e) & n.7, available at 
22  https://durkan.seattle.gov/2020/06/city-of-seattle-responds-to-the-capitol-hill-organized-protest/.  
23 
  ORDER - 6 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 23   Filed 10/16/20   Page 7 of 30
 
 
 
1 
2 
3 
4 
5 
6 
 
7 
  [Photos provided at FAC at ยถยถ 42โ43] 
8 
  Plaintiffs allege, โ[o]n information and belief,โ that the City considered the area 
9 
from Denny Way to Union Street and Thirteenth Avenue to Broadway Avenue to be a 
10 
โno responseโ zone, and it adopted a policy and practice of not entering CHOP except in 
11 
the case of โthe most seriousโ or โlife-threatening crimesโ; and even then, SPDโs 
12 
response was allegedly โweakโ and โdelayed.โ  Id. at ยถยถ 55โ56; see id. at ยถ 181(e). 
13 
  On June 20, at around 2:20 a.m., two people were shot in CHOP:  One victim died 
14 
before reaching the hospital, and the other victim was admitted with life-threatening 
15 
injuries.  Id. at ยถ 59.  According to Plaintiffs, a video posted on Facebook.com shows that 
16 
medical personnel responded to the first victim about 15 minutes into the video and that 
17 
police officers started to arrive three minutes later.  Id. at ยถ 60.  Once the police arrived, 
18 
the video allegedly shows that CHOP participants โimmediately surrounded, yelled at, 
19 
and pursuedโ the officers.  Id.  CHOP participants also allegedly created a human chain 
20 
to bar any further entry of the police.  Id.  That video allegedly shows that no government 
21 
official responded to the other victim, and that victim was transported to the hospital in โa 
22 
23 
  ORDER - 7 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 23   Filed 10/16/20   Page 8 of 30
 
 
 
1  plain white cargo van.โ  Id.  The police allegedly did not investigate that crime scene in 
2  the aftermath of the shooting, and no suspects have been identified or taken into custody.  
3  Id. 
4    The next day, on June 21, the Mayor allegedly issued a statement indicating that 
5  the โCity still had no plans to cease supporting CHOP and that the City was instead 
6  acting to work with and preserve CHOP.โ  Id. at ยถ 182(k).  That night, at about 11 p.m., 
7  another victim in CHOP was shot and was transported to the hospital by a private vehicle.  
8  Id. at ยถ 61. 
9    On June 22, the Mayor and the Police Chief gave a joint press conference, with the 
10  Mayor stating that โ[t]he cumulative impacts of gatherings and protests and the nighttime 
11  atmosphere and violence has led to increasingly difficult circumstances for our 
12  businesses and residents.โ  Id. at ยถ 174(f).  Similarly, the Police Chief stated that some 
13  CHOP participants were โengaging in shootings, a rape, assaults, burglary, arson, and 
14  property destruction.โ  Id. at ยถ 174(g).   
15    On June 29, in early hours, yet another shooting in CHOP occurred, during which 
16  more than a dozen shots were fired by โCHOP securityโ after a white jeep crashed into 
17  the barricades.  Id. at ยถยถ 63โ64.  This shooting left a 16-year-old dead and a 14-year-old 
18  in critical condition.  Id. at ยถ 63.2  According to Plaintiffs, no medical or police personnel 
19  responded to the crime scene at that time.  Id. at ยถ 65.  Instead, one of the victims was 
20 
 
21 
2 Plaintiffs allege that before CHOP was established, there had been no homicides in the entire Capitol 
Hill neighborhood in 2020 and in 2019, there had been only three homicides in the neighborhood.  Id. at 
22  ยถ 68. 
23 
  ORDER - 8 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 23   Filed 10/16/20   Page 9 of 30
 
 
 
1  transported out of CHOP by private vehicle, and the other was taken โto a meeting point 
2  with [the] Seattle Fire Departmentโ and then transported to the hospital.  Id.  By the time 
3  the police reached the crime scene, the police acknowledged that โit was very clear the 
4  crime scene had been disturbedโ and to date, no suspects have been identified or placed 
5  into custody.  Id. at ยถ 66.  The Police Chief gave a press conference that day, stating that 
6  โeverybody in city government has been talking about what we can do to have a 
7  reasonable response . . . , but we also recognize that a place where we have seen now two 
8  murders, multiple people injured, there needs to be some more action for public safety.  I 
9  think everyone can agree on that.โ  Id. at ยถ 174(h).  That same night, more shots were 
10  fired into the building of Plaintiff Onyx Condominium, possibly in connection with the 
11  earlier shooting, and at least one bullet came within a foot of a resident asleep in bed.  Id. 
12  at ยถ 67. 
13    On July 1, the City cleared the area occupied by CHOP.  Id. at ยถ 184.  At a press 
14  conference, the Police Chief stated that she was โstunned by the amount of graffiti, 
15  garbage, and property destructionโ in CHOP and that โwe donโt even know how much 
16  trauma people were experiencing because of what was happening in that area.โ  Id. at 
17  ยถ 79.  She also stated that โwhat has happened here on these streets over the last two 
18  weeksโfew weeks, that isโis lawless and itโs brutal and bottom line it is simply 
19  unacceptable.โ  Id. at ยถ 174(j).  Plaintiffs allege that the clearing of CHOP was โeasilyโ 
20  accomplished and โwithout violence on either side,โ demonstrating that the City could 
21  have and should have cleared the area much earlier.  Id. at ยถ 184. 
22 
23 
  ORDER - 9 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 23   Filed 10/16/20   Page 10 of 30
 
 
 
1    As a result of CHOPโs existence, Plaintiffs allege that they and the proposed class 
2  members suffered extensive economic damage and other harm.  Id. at ยถ 78.  For example: 
3  โข  Plaintiff SRJ Enterprises d/b/a Car Tender alleges that since early June 
2020, business revenues had declined by 40% from the months prior, id. at 
4  ยถ 83, and that its premises were vandalized by CHOP participants, 
including permanent damage to a fence, id. at ยถ 85.  On June 14, an 
5  individual broke into Car Tenderโs premises, vandalized and set fire to the 
shop, and accosted the ownerโs son with a knife and spike.  Id.  at ยถ 87.  
6  Although several 9-1-1 calls were made that night, the police never 
responded to the crime scene that evening.  Id. at ยถ 89.  Car Tenderโs owner 
7  and son apprehended the intruder, but they ultimately handed him over to 
an โangry mob of CHOP participantsโ who demanded that they release the 
8  intruder.  Id. at ยถ 90.  
9  โข  Plaintiff The Richmark Company d/b/a Richmark Label alleges that it 
incurred costs related to shipping delays and cancellations and suffered 
10  property damage because of CHOP participants.  Id. at ยถยถ 94, 96.  
Richmark Label also alleges that it is not receiving any โof the usual rental 
11  income it typically receives from the parking spaces.โ  Id. at ยถ 97. 
12  โข  Plaintiff Northwest Liquor and Wine LLC alleges that its average sales 
were down approximately 70% in June 2020.  Id. at ยถ 101. 
13 
โข  Plaintiff Sage Physical Therapy PLLC alleges that approximately 60% of 
its patients cancelled their appointments after CHOP was established.  Id. at 
14 
ยถ 109.  Sage also alleges that the internet cable in its building was cut, but 
the technician could not access the building due to CHOP barriersโ
15 
meaning Sage did not have access to its security cameras during this time 
period.  Id. at ยถ 108. 
16 
โข  Plaintiff Magdalena Sky d/b/a Tattoos and Fortune alleges that CHOPโs 
17 
barricades and encampments blocked vehicle and foot access to its studio, 
causing it to close its doors and preventing it from generating any revenue.  
18 
Id. at ยถ 113. 
19 
โข  Plaintiff Bergmanโs Lock and Key Services LLC alleges that it was forced 
to shorten its hours and eventually board up its premises due to graffiti and 
20 
vandalism by CHOP participants.  Id. at ยถ 117.  In June 2020, Lock and 
Keyโs revenues had allegedly declined by 60% due to CHOP.  Id. at ยถ 118. 
21 
โข  Plaintiff Matthew Ploszaj alleges that his apartment was broken into four 
22 
times during CHOPโs existence; each time, Ploszaj contacted the police, but 
23 
  ORDER - 10 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 23   Filed 10/16/20   Page 11 of 30
 
 
 
1  the police never responded.  Id. at ยถ 124.  On one occasion, an officer told 
Ploszaj that they could not respond to the building because of its location 
2  within CHOP and asked Ploszaj to instead meet him eight blocks from his 
apartment.  Id. at ยถ 125. 
3 
โข  Plaintiff Argento LLC allegedly called 9-1-1 four times regarding incidents 
4  involving CHOP participants, but was told that the police would not 
respond to his area unless there was a violent incident.  Id. at ยถ 132. 
5 
โข  Plaintiff Onyx Homeowners Association alleges that it and its residents 
called 9-1-1 to report graffiti and other acts of vandalism by CHOP 
6 
participants, but they received no response or direction from the City.  Id. at 
ยถ 135.  On June 29, shots were fired into the Onyx Condominium building, 
7 
with at least one bullet coming within a foot of a resident asleep in bed.  Id. 
at ยถ 140.

7  A.  Rule 12(b)(6) Standard 
8    To survive a motion to dismiss under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6), โa 
9  complaint must contain sufficient factual matter, accepted as true, to โstate a claim to 
10  relief that is plausible on its face.โโ  Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662, 678, 129 S. Ct. 1937, 
11  173 L. Ed. 2d 868 (2009) (quoting Bell Atl. Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 570, 127 S. 
12  Ct. 1955, 167 L. Ed. 2d 929 (2007)).  โA claim has facial plausibility when the plaintiff 
13  pleads factual content that allows the court to draw the reasonable inference that the 
14  defendant is liable for the misconduct alleged.โ  Id. 
15  B.  Municipal Liability 
16    โLocal governing bodies . . . can be sued directly under [42 U.S.C. ยง 1983] for 
17  monetary, declaratory, or injunctive relief where . . . the action that is alleged to be 
18  unconstitutional implements or executes a policy statement, ordinance, regulation, or 
19  decision officially adopted and promulgated by that bodyโs officers.โ  Monell v. Depโt of

4  suffered.โ  Galen v. County of Los Angeles, 477 F.3d 652, 667 (9th Cir. 2007) (quoting

16  C.  Due Process Violations 
17  1.  Procedural Due Process Violation โ First Cause of Action 
18    The Fourteenth Amendment provides: โ[N]or shall any State deprive any person 
19  of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law.โ  U.S. Const. amend. XIV, ยง 1.  
20  To prevail on a procedural due process claim, a ยง 1983 plaintiff must establish โ(1) a 
21  liberty or property interest protected by the Constitution; (2) a deprivation of the interest 
22  by the government; and (3) lack of process.โ  Portman v. County of Santa Clara, 995

2  Constitution.โ  Bd. of Regents of State Colls. v. Roth, 408 U.S. 564, 577, 92 S. Ct. 2701, 
3  33 L. Ed. 2d 548 (1972).  โRather they are created and their dimensions are defined by 
4  existing rules or understandings that stem from an independent source such as state lawโ
5  rules or understandings that secure certain benefits and that support claims of entitlement 
6  to those benefits.โ  Id.  If a plaintiff is entitled to such benefits, even certain โtemporary 
7  or partial impairments of property rights . . . are sufficient to merit due process 
8  protection.โ  Connecticut v. Doehr, 501 U.S. 1, 111 S. Ct. 2105, 115 L. Ed. 2d 1 (1991).

6  D.  Unlawful Taking โ Third Cause of Action 
7    The Takings Clause, which applies to local governments through the Fourteenth 
8  Amendment, provides: โ[N]or shall private property be taken for public use, without just 
9  compensation.โ  U.S. Const. amend. V; see Webbโs Fabulous Pharmacies, Inc. v. 
10  Beckwith, 449 U.S. 155, 160, 101 S. Ct. 446, 66 L. Ed. 2d 358 (1980).  To establish a 
11  violation of the Takings Clause, a plaintiff must show that โโan independent source such 
12  as state lawโ . . . define[s] the range of interests that qualify for protection as โpropertyโ 
13  under the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments.โ  Lucas v. S.C. Coastal Council, 505 U.S. 
14  1003, 1030, 112 S. Ct. 2886, 120 L. Ed. 2d 798 (1992) (quoting Roth, 408 U.S. at 577); 
15  see Vandevere v. Lloyd, 644 F.3d 957, 963 (9th Cir. 2011).  Once a state-created property 
16  right is established, the Court must then determine โwhether [that] property right has been 
17  abridged improperly (taken without just compensation) or whether a plaintiff has given 
18  up the right to assert such a claim,โ which are โquestion[s] of federal law.โ  Vandevere, 
19  644 F.3d at 963โ64. 
20    Under Washington law, โ[t]he right of access of an abutting property owner to a 
21  public right-of-way is a property right which if taken or damaged for a public use 
22  requires compensation.โ  Keiffer, 89 Wn.2d at 372.  Washington courts generally 
23 
  ORDER - 20 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 23   Filed 10/16/20   Page 21 of 30
 
 
 
1  distinguish between an unlawful taking, which โis a permanent (or recurring) invasion of 
2  private property,โ and a โtemporary interference with a private property right, which is 
3  not continuous nor likely to be reoccurring,โ N. Pac. Ry. Co. v. Sunnyside Valley 
4  Irrigation Dist., 85 Wn.2d 920, 924, 540 P.2d 1387 (1975) (citations omitted).  This 
5  distinction loses force, however, where the government โcompels a property owner to 
6  suffer a โphysical invasionโ or โoccupationโ of his or her property.โ  Guimont, 121 Wn.2d 
7  at 597โ98 & n.3; see also Lucas, 505 U.S. at 1030 n.17; id. at 1033 (Kennedy, J., 
8  concurring). 
9  Both Washington and federal courts โare reluctant to find that a compensable 
10  taking occurred where the government temporarily used or destroyed property in times of 
11  emergency.โ  Citoli v. City of Seattle, 115 Wn. App. 459, 489, 61 P.3d 1165, 1169 (2002) 
12  (citing Natโl Bd. of Young Menโs Christian Assโns v. United States (YMCA), 395 U.S. 85, 
13  89 S. Ct. 1511, 23 L.Ed.2d 117 (1969)).  For example, in Monarch Ins. Co. v. District of 
14  Columbia, 353 F. Supp. 1249 (D.D.C. 1973), affโd sub nom Aetna Ins. Co. v. United 
15  States, 497 F.2d 683 (D.C. Cir. 1974), the district court dismissed the plaintiffโs takings 
16  claim based on allegations that the governmentโs โriot control program . . . intentionally 
17  sacrificed [the plaintiffโs] private property.โ  Id. at 1255โ56.  There, the court reasoned 
18  that โjudgments about where . . . police should be stationed and what degree of force 
19  should be exerted to provide adequate protection . . . in riot control situations . . . are best 
20  left to officials directly responsible to the electorate.โ  Id. at 1256 (quoting YMCA, 395 
21  U.S. at 95 (Harlan, J., concurring)).

1  however, the City is not liable under ยง 1983 simply because its response to the creation of 
2  CHOP was โtoo little, too late,โ id. at 1255, or because the City failed to prevent CHOP 
3  participants from physically invading their properties, cf. Citoli, 115 Wn. App. at 488.7  
4  Rather, Plaintiffs plausibly assert that the Cityโs endorsement of, and the provision of 
5  material support to, CHOP set in motion a series of acts by certain CHOP participants, 
6  who the City knew or reasonably should have known would deprive Plaintiffs of 
7  protected property interests.  FAC at ยถยถ 174, 182, 212โ13.  These allegations support the 
8  claim that the Cityโs conduct was โcausally related to [the] private misconductโ and it 
9  was โsufficiently direct and substantial to require compensation under the Fifth 
10  Amendment.โ  YMCA, 395 U.S. at 93. 
11  E.  Equal Protection Violation โ Fourth Cause of Action  
12    โ[N]or shall any State . . . deny to any person within its jurisdiction the equal 
13  protection of the laws.โ  U.S. Const. amend. XIV, ยง 1.  โโEqual protectionโ . . . 
14  emphasizes disparity in treatment by a State between classes of individuals whose 
15  situations are arguably indistinguishable.โ  Ross v. Moffit, 417 U.S. 600, 609, 94 S. Ct. 
16  2437, 41 L. Ed. 2d 341 (1974).  Accordingly, the first step in analyzing an equal 
17  protection challenge โis to identify the stateโs classification of groups,โ i.e., the plaintiffโs 
18  โclassified groupโ and the โcontrol group . . . composed of individuals who are similarly 
19  situated to those in the classified group in respects that are relevant to the stateโs 
20 
 
21 
7 Unlike Plaintiffs in this case, the plaintiff in Citoli failed to allege a protected property interest.  115 Wn. 
22  App. at 489. 
23 
  ORDER - 23 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 23   Filed 10/16/20   Page 24 of 30
 
 
 
1  challenged policy.โ  Gallinger v. Becerra, 898 F.3d 1012, 1016 (9th Cir. 2018) (citation 
2  omitted).  โThe groups must be comprised of similarly situated persons so that the factor 
3  motivating the alleged discrimination can be identified.โ  Thornton v. City of St. Helens, 
4  425 F.3d 1158, 1167 (9th Cir. 2005).  โAn equal protection claim will not lie by 
5  โconflating all persons not injured into a preferred class receiving better treatmentโ than 
6  the plaintiff.โ  Id. (citation omitted).  As the court noted in Squaw Valley Dev. Co. v. 
7  Goldberg, 375 F.3d 936 (9th Cir. 2004), overruled on other grounds by Lingle v. 
8  Chevron U.S.A. Inc., 544 U.S. 528, 125 S. Ct. 2074, 161 L. Ed. 2d 876 (2005), in any 
9  equal protection analysis, a plaintiff must compare โapples to apples.โ  Id. at 945; see 
10  also Ruston v. Town Bd. for the Town of Skaneateles, 610 F.3d 55, 59 (2d Cir. 2010) 
11  (โClass-of-one plaintiffs must show an extremely high degree of similarity between 
12  themselves and the persons to whom they compare themselves.โ); accord Hood Canal 
13  Sand & Gravel, LLC v. Brady, 129 F. Supp. 3d 1118, 1125 (W.D. Wash. 2015).8 
14    Plaintiffs appear to identify two classifications of groups that were purportedly 
15  treated differently in violation of the Equal Protection Clause: (1) โareas occupied by 
16  CHOP versus other areas of the City,โ FAC at ยถยถ 220โ21; and (2) Plaintiffs versus CHOP 
17  participants, id. at ยถยถ 222, 224.  With respect to the first grouping, Plaintiffs have failed to 
18  plausibly allege that individuals living in โareas occupied by CHOPโ are similarly 
19  situated to individuals living in โother areas of the City.โ  Although Plaintiffs plausibly 
20 
 
21 
8 The City characterizes Plaintiffsโ claim as a โclass of oneโ equal protection claim, and Plaintiffs 
22  acknowledge that they โpled this theory.โ  Response (docket no. 12 at 24 & n.6); see FAC at ยถ 225. 
23 
  ORDER - 24 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 23   Filed 10/16/20   Page 25 of 30
 
 
 
1  allege that the City treated the two groups differently after CHOP was created, FAC at 
2  ยถยถ 226โ27, they do not allege any facts suggesting that they are similarly situated to the 
3  control group, e.g., that the other areas in the city were also occupied by a large group of 
4  organizers.  To the contrary, Plaintiffsโ allegations emphasize the unprecedented nature 
5  of CHOPโs creationโthat after SPD abandoned the East Precinct, organizers โwho 
6  gathered on Capitol Hillโ โform[ed]โ or โcreatedโ CHOP.  Id. at ยถยถ 1โ2, 35โ37.  By 
7  failing to allege facts showing that other areas of the City were similarly situated to areas 
8  occupied by CHOP, Plaintiffs merely conflate all persons not injured outside of CHOP 
9  into a preferred class.  Thornton, 425 F.3d at 1167; see Ruston, 610 F.3d at 60 
10  (concluding that none of the alleged control-group properties were similar to plaintiffโs 
11  proposed development, โlet alone so similar that no rational person could see them as 
12  differentโ). 
13    The second grouping asserted by PlaintiffsโPlaintiffs versus CHOP 
14  participantsโsuffers from similar defects.  Plaintiffs argue that the โbias โin favorโโ of 
15  CHOP participants, based on the Cityโs preference for their viewpoints, violates the 
16  Equal Protection Clause โbecause such favoritism necessarily entails disfavor to others.โ  
17  Response (docket no. 12 at 26); see FAC at ยถยถ 221โ22.  The only case that Plaintiffs cite 
18  in support of that novel argument is Elliot-Park v. Manglona, 592 F.3d 1003 (9th Cir. 
19  2010); but in that case, the Ninth Circuit concluded that the plaintiff plausibly asserted an 
20  equal protection claim against police officers based on allegations that her perpetrator 
21  โwas given a pass by the police because of the officersโ alleged racial bias not only in 
22  favor of [her perpetrator] as a Micronesian, but also against her as a Korean.โ  Id. at 1006 
23 
  ORDER - 25 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 23   Filed 10/16/20   Page 26 of 30
 
 
 
1  (emphasis added).  Put simply, an allegation that the government favors a certain class or 
2  viewpoint, standing alone, is insufficient to show that the government necessarily 
3  disfavors the plaintiffโs alleged class or viewpoint for purposes of equal protection 
4  analysis.  See Gallinger, 898 F.3d at 1021 (โAccommodating one interest group is not 
5  equivalent to intentionally harming another.โ). 
6    Not only do Plaintiffs fail to allege that they hold a viewpoint that is disfavored by 
7  the City, they also allege that they โsupport the efforts of those like Black Lives Matter 
8  who . . . are bringing issues such as systemic racism and unfair violence against African 
9  Americans by police to the forefront of the national consciousnessโ and that they 
10  โsupport the free-speech rights of many of those who gathered on Capitol Hill to form 
11  what has been called . . . โCHOP.โโ  FAC at ยถยถ 1, 12.  According to the Plaintiffs, that 
12  viewpoint is also favored by the City.  Id. at ยถยถ 10, 218, 221โ24. 
13    Even assuming that the asserted classes are similarly situated, the Cityโs actions 
14  are โpresumed to be valid and will be sustained if the classification . . . is rationally 
15  related to a legitimate state interest.โ  Gallinger, 898 F.3d at 1017; FCC v. Beach 
16  Comms., Inc., 508 U.S. 307, 313, 113 S. Ct. 2096, 124 L. Ed. 2d 211 (1993) (โIn areas of 
17  social and economic policy, a statutory classification that neither proceeds along suspect 
18  lines nor infringes fundamental constitutional rights must be upheld against [an] equal 
19  protection challenge if there is any reasonably conceivable state of facts that could 
20  provide a rational basis for the classification.โ).  Plaintiffs argue that the Court should 
21  apply heightened scrutiny in this case because the Cityโs alleged actions โaffected the 
22  fundamental right of free speech.โ  Response (docket no. 12 at 26โ27).  However, 
23 
  ORDER - 26 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 23   Filed 10/16/20   Page 27 of 30
 
 
 
1  Plaintiffs do not plausibly allege that the City disfavored the Plaintiffsโ viewpoint or 
2  treated them differently on that basis.  The Court concludes that rational-basis review 
3  applies to this case, as currently pleaded.  See Beach Comms., 508 U.S. at 313; see also 
4  Squaw Valley, 375 F.3d at 944.9 
5    Applying rational-basis review, Plaintiffโs allegations are insufficient to overcome 
6  the presumption that the Cityโs different treatment of CHOP residents was rational 
7  because there is simply no indication that other areas of the city were being โoverrunโ or 
8  โoccupiedโ by a large group of protestors.  See FAC at ยถยถ 2โ5; Gallinger, 898 F.3d at 
9  1018โ20 (refusing โto second-guessโ the governmentโs determination that its unequal 
10  treatment advanced legitimate governmental interests, including the protection of retired 
11  peace officers and public safety, and affirming the district courtโs dismissal of the equal 
12  protection claim). 
13    Absent any allegations indicating that the City intentionally treated Plaintiffs 
14  differently than similarly situated individuals, and without any rational basis for doing so, 
15  the Court concludes that Plaintiffs did not plead sufficient facts to support their equal 
16  protection claim.  The claim is dismissed without prejudice.  See Lopez v. Smith, 203 F.3d 
17  1122, 1130 (9th Cir. 2000) (concluding that โa district court should grant leave to amend 
18  even if no request to amend the pleading was made, unless it determines that the pleading 
19  could not possibly be cured by the allegation of other factsโ) (citation omitted). 
20 
 
21 
9 Even if the Court were to apply heightened scrutiny, Plaintiffsโ conclusory allegation that other groups 
22  were similarly situated are nonetheless insufficient to support their equal protection challenge. 
23 
  ORDER - 27 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 23   Filed 10/16/20   Page 28 of 30
 
 
 
1  F.  Class Certification 
2    In determining whether discovery is necessary to establish the existence of a class 
3  under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23, โthe better and more advisable practice for a 
4  District Court to follow is to afford the litigants an opportunity to present evidence as to 
5  whether a class action was maintainable.โ  Doninger v. Pac. Nw. Bell, Inc., 564 F.2d 
6  1304, 1313 (9th Cir. 1977).  The federal authority addressing this issue โstand[s] for the 
7  unremarkable position that often the pleadings alone will not resolve the question of class 
8  certification and that some discovery will be warranted.โ  Vinole v. Countrywide Home 
9  Loans, Inc., 571 F.3d 935, 942 & n.6 (9th Cir. 2009); cf. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. Dukes, 
10  564 U.S. 338, 350, 131 S. Ct. 2541, 180 L. Ed. 2d 374 (2011) (concluding that โRule 23 
11  does not set forth a mere pleading standardโ and that โ[a] party seeking class 
12  certification . . . must be prepared to prove that there are in fact . . . common questions of 
13  law or fact, etc.โ).  A district court may deny class certification, without first providing 
14  proposed class members an opportunity to conduct discovery, only under limited 
15  circumstancesโwhere, for example, they โfail to make even a prima facie showing of 
16  Rule 23โs prerequisites.โ See Doninger, 564 F.2d at 1313. 
17    The Court concludes that it would be improper to decide class certification on the 
18  pleadings.  It is entirely plausible that Plaintiffs, after discovery, could present evidence 
19  consistent with the allegations in the FAC to make a prima facie showing of Rule 23โs 
20  prerequisites, including the commonality requirement and the predominance requirement.  
21  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(2), (b)(3).  For example, Plaintiffsโ evidence could plausibly show 
22  that the City adopted a policy and practice of endorsing CHOP, or that the City knew or 
23 
  ORDER - 28 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 23   Filed 10/16/20   Page 29 of 30
 
 
 
1  should have known that its actions would result in harm to Plaintiffs and the proposed 
2  class members.  FAC at ยถ 189; see also id. at ยถยถ 174, 182; see Dukes, 564 U.S. at 350 
3  (requiring that class membersโ claims โdepend upon a common contentionโ and that the 
4  common contention be โcapable of classwide resolutionโwhich means that 
5  determination of its truth or falsity will resolve an issue that is central to the validity of 
6  each one of the claims in one strokeโ).  The Court will therefore afford Plaintiffs an 
7  opportunity to discover evidence to demonstrate whether there are in fact common 
8  questions that predominate over individualized inquires.  Cf. Doninger, 564 F.2d at 1313; 
9  Vinole, 571 F.3d at 942, 948 (concluding that the district court did not abuse discretion in 
10  granting defendantโs motion to deny class certification where plaintiffs โwere provided 
11  with adequate time in which to conduct discovery related to the question of class 
12  certificationโ).  At this stage in the proceedings, the Cityโs motion to deny class 
13  certification is DENIED without prejudice pending discovery.  
14  Conclusion 
15  For the foregoing reasons, the Court ORDERS: 
16  (1)  The motion to dismiss the fourth cause of action based on equal protection 
17  is GRANTED.  This claim is dismissed without prejudice.  Plaintiffs may electronically 
18  file a second amended complaint via the Case Management and Electronic Case Filing 
19  (โCM/ECFโ) system within fourteen (14) days of the date of this Order. 
20  (2)  Except as provided in paragraph (1), the motion to dismiss all other causes 
21  of action is DENIED. 
22 
23 
  ORDER - 29 
 

 
Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 23   Filed 10/16/20   Page 30 of 30
 
 
 
1  (3)  The motion to deny class certification is DENIED without prejudice 
2  pending discovery for the reasons stated in this Order; 
3  (4)  The motion to stay discovery, docket no. 16, is now DENIED as moot; and 
4  (5)  The Clerk is directed to send a copy of this Order to all counsel of record. 
5  IT IS SO ORDERED. 
6  Dated this 16th day of October, 2020. 
7 
A
8 
 
9  Thomas S. Zilly 
United States District Judge

Washington limited liability company, on 
1 
behalf of themselves and others similarly 
situated, 
2 
 
  Plaintiffs, 
3 
 
4    vs. 
 
5  CITY OF SEATTLE, 
  Defendant. 
6   
 
7 
8    Plaintiffs hereby allege as follows: 
9  I.  OVERVIEW 
10  1.  The  rights  of  free  speech  and  to  peaceably  assemble  are  enshrined  in  our 
11  constitutional tradition. Plaintiffs support free-speech rights and support the efforts of those like 
12  Black Lives Matter who, by exercising such rights, are bringing issues such as systemic racism 
13  and  unfair  violence  against  African  Americans  by  police  to  the  forefront  of  the  national 
14  consciousness.  Specifically,  Plaintiffs  support  the  free-speech  rights  of  many  of  those  who 
15  gathered on Capitol Hill to form what has been called โCHAZ,โ standing for the โCapitol Hill 
16  Autonomous Zone,โ or โCHOPโ for โCapitol Hill Organized Protestโ or โCapitol Hill Occupying 
17  Protest.โ1   
18  2.  This lawsuit does not seek to undermine CHOP participantsโ message or present a 
19  counter-message.  Rather,  this  lawsuit  is  about  the  constitutional  and  other  legal  rights  of 
20  Plaintiffsโbusinesses, employees, and residents in and around CHOPโwhich were overrun by 
21  the City of Seattleโs unprecedented decision to abandon and close off an entire city neighborhood, 
22  leaving  it  unchecked  by  the  police,  unserved  by  fire  and  emergency  health  services,  and 
23  inaccessible to the public at large. The Cityโs decision subjected businesses, employees, and 
24 
 
25 
1 This complaint primarily refers to the area as โCHOP,โ and the people who participated in CHOP who are not 
businesses, employees, or residents of the area as โCHOP participants.โ 
 
27  SECOND AMENDED CLASS ACTION    LAW OFFICES 
CALFO EAKES LLP 
COMPLAINT   1301 SECOND AVENUE, SUITE 2800 
28  Case No. 2:20-cv-00983 TSZ - 2  TEL,S (E2A06T)T 4L0E7,- 2W20A0S  H FIANXG,T (O20N6 )9 8410071-2 224 
 
 
29 

Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 28   Filed 10/30/20   Page 3 of 62
 
1  residents of that neighborhood to extensive property damage, public safety dangers, and an 
2  inability to use and access their properties. 
3  3.  On June 8, 2020, the City of Seattle (โthe Cityโ) abruptly deserted the Seattle Police 
4  Departmentโs East Precinct on the corner of Twelfth Avenue and E. Pine Street in Seattleโs Capitol 
5  Hill neighborhood, leaving behind numerous barriers that had previously been used as a line 
6  between police and protesters. 
7  4.  When the City abandoned the precinct and the nearby barriers, a number of 
8  individuals who had been in the area took control of the barriers and used them to block off streets 
9  in an area around the East Precinct.  
10  5.  In  the  days  and  weeks  after  the  City  abandoned  the  East  Precinct,  CHOP 
11  participants occupied the public streets, sidewalks, and parks in the area at all hours of the day and 
12  night. Rather than seeking to restore order and protect the residents and property owners within 
13  CHOP, the City instead chose to actively endorse, enable, and participate in the occupation of 
14  CHOP.  
15  6.  The City provided Cal Anderson Park, a public park located at the center of CHOP,  
16  to CHOP for use as the staging ground supporting CHOPโs occupation of the surrounding area. 
17  Supported by the City, countless CHOP participants resided in the park at all times of day and 
18  night, having turned it into a tent city. At any given time, hundreds of CHOP participants camped 
19  out in the park. Violence, vandalism, excessive noise, public drug use, and other crimes were 
20  rampant within the park.  
21  7.  The Cityโs conduct resulted in CHOP being blocked off from public access. Among 
22  other conduct detailed below, the City provided the participants with concrete barriers to use to 
23  block the streets, which CHOP participants indeed used to barricade the streets and create borders. 
24  These borders, at times, were guarded by armed CHOP participants who oversaw who could or 
25  could not enter CHOP. As a result, the streets were barred to most all vehicular traffic, making it 
 
27  SECOND AMENDED CLASS ACTION    LAW OFFICES 
CALFO EAKES LLP 
COMPLAINT   1301 SECOND AVENUE, SUITE 2800 
28  Case No. 2:20-cv-00983 TSZ - 3  TEL,S (E2A06T)T 4L0E7,- 2W20A0S  H FIANXG,T (O20N6 )9 8410071-2 224 
 
 
29 

Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 28   Filed 10/30/20   Page 4 of 62
 
1  virtually impossible for residents and businesses to access their buildings, receive deliveries, and 
2  provide goods and services to the few customers willing to enter CHOP.  
3  8.  The Cityโs conduct also resulted in the elimination of basic public safety within 
4  CHOP and nearby areas. For example, the City enacted a policy under which police would not 
5  enter the CHOP area except during life-and-death emergencies, and, even in those situations, the 
6  response was, at best, muted and late. After a fatal shooting in the early morning of June 20, 2020, 
7  for example, officers did not even approach the area of the shooting until approximately 20 minutes 
8  after the shooting, and no professional medical response was available for at least 15 minutes. At 
9  other times, even during life-and-death emergencies, the police acquiesced to demands from 
10  CHOP participants that they abandon the area. The City acknowledged the serious safety issues it 
11  created,  in  particular  noting  that  there  were  โdangerous  conditionsโ  at  night,  but  the  City 
12  nonetheless chose to maintain its policy of providing resources and support to the CHOP occupiers.  
13  9.  The Cityโs conduct enabled the widespread destruction and vandalism of private 
14  property. Graffiti was and is pervasive throughout the areaโit is not only on barriers, streets, 
15  sidewalks, but also on nearly every private building within CHOP. Graffiti that was painted over 
16  almost immediately returned, and property owners were told by CHOP participants that if they 
17  dared to paint over graffiti, their buildings would be more severely vandalized or even burned to 
18  the ground. The City did nothing to prevent this conduct from June 8, 2020 to July 1, 2020, but, 
19  instead, actively endorsed and supported the ongoing occupation of the CHOP area and the 
20  destruction of property that accompanied it. As a result, property owners and their tenants were 
21  not able to fully use their properties. Property owners and tenants, for instance, had to lock and 
22  barricade their garages and loading areas at risk of having CHOP participants entering and 
23  vandalizing them. 
24  10.  The property owners, businesses, and residents in the area suffered ever-increasing 
25  property damage and economic loss every day that CHOP existed in their neighborhood, all 
 
27  SECOND AMENDED CLASS ACTION    LAW OFFICES 
CALFO EAKES LLP 
COMPLAINT   1301 SECOND AVENUE, SUITE 2800 
28  Case No. 2:20-cv-00983 TSZ - 4  TEL,S (E2A06T)T 4L0E7,- 2W20A0S  H FIANXG,T (O20N6 )9 8410071-2 224 
 
 
29 

Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 28   Filed 10/30/20   Page 5 of 62
 
1  because of the Cityโs active support, encouragement, and endorsement of the occupation. In 
2  particular, Seattle Mayor Jenny Durkan provided the CHOP participants with not just tangible 
3  resources but also a de facto stamp of approval. Her tweets, interviews, and other statements made 
4  it clear that the City was fully aware of what is happening, had no plan or timeline for remedying 
5  the ongoing harm, and in fact viewed the occupation of Capitol Hill as something akin to a 
6  perpetual block party, which the City wanted to support because of the viewpoints of CHOP 
7  participants. 
8  11.  Plaintiffs and others repeatedly pleaded with Mayor Durkan and others to cease 
9  enabling the destruction of their property and the imminent dangers posed to them and their 
10  neighborhood. But the City did not listen, or did not care, and it was only after Plaintiffs had to 
11  resort to litigation to make themselves heard that the City finally took action to disband CHOP 
12  12.  Again,  this  case  is  not  about  Plaintiffsโ  agreement  or  disagreement  with  the 
13  inspiration for CHOP, or the viewpoints expressed by the people occupying that area. Instead, it 
14  is about the Cityโs active, knowing endorsement and support of a destructive occupation of a 
15  neighborhood to the detriment of the well-being of those who live and work in that neighborhood. 
16  II.  PARTIES 
17  13.  Plaintiffs are residents, tenants, property owners, and small businesses in Seattleโs 
18  Capitol Hill neighborhood that have been harmed by CHOP.  
19  14.  Plaintiff Hunters Capital LLC (โHunters Capitalโ) is a Washington limited liability 
20  company with its principal place of business in King County, Washington. Hunters Capital is a 
21  real-estate development, investment, and management company, headquartered near Cal Anderson 
22  Park in the Capitol Hill neighborhood with offices in the zone occupied by CHOP at 1620 
23  Broadway Seattle, Washington. Hunters Capital owns and manages a portfolio of commercial, 
24  multi-family residential, and mixed-use properties in the Capitol Hill neighborhood within and 
25  around CHOP, including 500 E. Pike Street, 1517 12th Avenue, 401 E. Pine Street, 1000 E. Pike 
 
27  SECOND AMENDED CLASS ACTION    LAW OFFICES 
CALFO EAKES LLP 
COMPLAINT   1301 SECOND AVENUE, SUITE 2800 
28  Case No. 2:20-cv-00983 TSZ - 5  TEL,S (E2A06T)T 4L0E7,- 2W20A0S  H FIANXG,T (O20N6 )9 8410071-2 224 
 
 
29 

Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 28   Filed 10/30/20   Page 6 of 62

12  IV.  FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS 
13  A.  The Creation of CHOP 
14  34.  On June 8, 2020, with protests ongoing near the East Precinct, the City emptied the 
15  East Precinct of all weapons and valuables, and then abandoned it. 
16  35.  The City left behind at the precinct and in the surrounding areas large barriers that 
17  had been used in previous days to try to limit the movements of protesters. 
18  36.  Predictably, almost immediately after the SPD abandoned the precinct and the 
19  barriers, CHOP participants used the barriers to block off streets in the area and create a โno-copโ 
20  zone. Initially, the blocked-off area extended to all streets within one block from the precinct. 
21  37.  Without  any  police  presence,  the  CHOP  participants  organized  themselves, 
22  declared the area โFree Capitol Hill,โ and stationed guards by the barriers that the City had 
23  abandoned, thereby creating borders for the occupied area. The area later expanded, was referred 
24  to as CHAZ for several days, and eventually became known as CHOP.

1  i.  Mayor Durkan tweeted on June 16, 2020: โThe #CHOP has emerged as a

8  died, Mayor Durkan issued a statement indicating that the City still had no plans to

10  CHOP. 
11  174.  The City changed its tone after it learned that this lawsuit would be filed, and 
12  especially after Plaintiffs filed their first complaint. This included finally clearing CHOP of 
13  barricades and CHOP participants on July 1, 2020, in the face of an impending motion for a 
14  temporary restraining order. But the Cityโs earlier assistance and endorsement of CHOP and 
15  CHOP participants caused, and continue to cause, harm to Plaintiffs and the Class that would not 
16  have occurred absent the Cityโs actions. 
17  175.  The clearing of the area on July 1, 2020, was easily and accomplished without 
18  violence on either side, demonstrating that the City could have and should have cleared the area 
19  far earlier.

1  184.  The issues that Class members have in common predominate over any individual

4  any, pale by comparison to the numerous common questions that dominate. The injuries sustained 
5  by the Class members flow, in each instance, from a common nucleus of operative facts. 
6  185.  A class action is superior to other available methods for the fair and efficient 
7  adjudication of this controversy because joinder of all class members is impracticable. The 
8  prosecution of separate actions by individual members of the Class would impose heavy burdens 
9  upon the courts and the City and would create a risk of inconsistent or varying adjudications of the 
10  questions of law and fact common to the Class. A class action would achieve substantial economies 
11  of time, effort, and expense, and would assure uniformity of decision as to persons similarly 
12  situated without sacrificing procedural fairness. Individual litigation of the legal and factual issues 
13  raised by the conduct of the City would increase delay and expense to all parties and to the court 
14  system. The class action device presents far fewer management difficulties and provides the 
15  benefits of a single, uniform adjudication, economies of scale and comprehensive supervision by 
16  a single court. Given the similar nature of the claims of the members of the Class and the uniform 
17  application of Washington and federal law to the claims of Plaintiffs and the members of the Class, 
18  the Classโs claims can and will be most effectively managed by a class action.

9    Plaintiffs hereby allege as follows: 
10  I.  OVERVIEW 
11  1.  The  rights  of  free  speech  and  to  peaceably  assemble  are  enshrined  in  our 
12  constitutional tradition. Plaintiffs support free-speech rights and support the efforts of those like 
13  Black Lives Matter who, by exercising such rights, are bringing issues such as systemic racism 
14  and  unfair  violence  against  African  Americans  by  police  to  the  forefront  of  the  national 
15  consciousness.  Specifically,  Plaintiffs  support  the  free-speech  rights  of  many  of  those  who 
16  gathered on Capitol Hill to form what has been called โCHAZ,โ standing for the โCapitol Hill 
17  Autonomous Zone,โ or โCHOPโ for โCapitol Hill Organized Protestโ or โCapitol Hill Occupying 
18  Protest.โ1   
19  2.  This lawsuit does not seek to undermine CHOP participantsโ message or present a 
20  counter-message.  Rather,  this  lawsuit  is  about  the  constitutional  and  other  legal  rights  of 
21  Plaintiffsโbusinesses, employees, and residents in and around CHOPโwhich were overrun by 
22  the City of Seattleโs unprecedented decision to abandon and close off an entire city neighborhood, 
23  leaving  it  unchecked  by  the  police,  unserved  by  fire  and  emergency  health  services,  and 
24  inaccessible to the public at large. The Cityโs decision subjected businesses, employees, and 
 
25 
1 This complaint primarily refers to the area as โCHOP,โ and the people who participated in CHOP who are not 
businesses, employees, or residents of the area as โCHOP participants.โ 
 
27 
FIRST AMENDED CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT    LAW OFFICES 
CALFO EAKES LLP 
Case No. 2:20-cv-00983 TSZ - 2  1301 SECOND AVENUE, SUITE 2800 
28 
  SEATTLE, WASHINGTON 98101

1  residents of that neighborhood to extensive property damage, public safety dangers, and an 
2  inability to use and access their properties. 
3  3.  On June 8, 2020, the City of Seattle (โthe Cityโ) abruptly deserted the Seattle Police 
4  Departmentโs East Precinct on the corner of Twelfth Avenue and E. Pine Street in Seattleโs Capitol 
5  Hill neighborhood, leaving behind numerous barriers that had previously been used as a line 
6  between police and protesters. 
7  4.  When the City abandoned the precinct and the nearby barriers, a number of 
8  individuals who had been in the area took control of the barriers and used them to block off streets 
9  in an area around the East Precinct.  
10  5.  In  the  days  and  weeks  after  the  City  abandoned  the  East  Precinct,  CHOP 
11  participants occupied the public streets, sidewalks, and parks in the area at all hours of the day and 
12  night. Rather than seeking to restore order and protect the residents and property owners within 
13  CHOP, the City instead chose to actively endorse, enable, and participate in the occupation of 
14  CHOP.  
15  6.  The City provided Cal Anderson Park, a public park located at the center of CHOP,  
16  to CHOP for use as the staging ground supporting CHOPโs occupation of the surrounding area. 
17  Supported by the City, countless CHOP participants resided in the park at all times of day and 
18  night, having turned it into a tent city. At any given time, hundreds of CHOP participants camped 
19  out in the park. Violence, vandalism, excessive noise, public drug use, and other crimes were 
20  rampant within the park.  
21  7.  The Cityโs conduct resulted in CHOP being blocked off from public access. Among 
22  other conduct detailed below, the City provided the participants with concrete barriers to use to 
23  block the streets, which CHOP participants indeed used to barricade the streets and create borders. 
24  These borders, at times, were guarded by armed CHOP participants who oversaw who could or 
25  could not enter CHOP. As a result, the streets were barred to most all vehicular traffic, making it 
 
27

17  IV.  FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS 
18  A.  The Creation of CHOP 
19  35.  On June 8, 2020, with protests ongoing near the East Precinct, the City emptied the 
20  East Precinct of all weapons and valuables, and then abandoned it. 
21  36.  The City left behind at the precinct and in the surrounding areas large barriers that 
22  had been used in previous days to try to limit the movements of protesters. 
23  37.  Predictably, almost immediately after the SPD abandoned the precinct and the 
24  barriers, CHOP participants used the barriers to block off streets in the area and create a โno-copโ 
25  zone. Initially, the blocked-off area extended to all streets within one block from the precinct.

8  194.  A class action is superior to other available methods for the fair and efficient 
9  adjudication of this controversy because joinder of all class members is impracticable. The 
10  prosecution of separate actions by individual members of the Class would impose heavy burdens 
11  upon the courts and the City and would create a risk of inconsistent or varying adjudications of the 
12  questions of law and fact common to the Class. A class action would achieve substantial economies 
13  of time, effort, and expense, and would assure uniformity of decision as to persons similarly 
14  situated without sacrificing procedural fairness. Individual litigation of the legal and factual issues 
15  raised by the conduct of the City would increase delay and expense to all parties and to the court 
16  system. The class action device presents far fewer management difficulties and provides the 
17  benefits of a single, uniform adjudication, economies of scale and comprehensive supervision by 
18  a single court. Given the similar nature of the claims of the members of the Class and the uniform 
19  application of Washington and federal law to the claims of Plaintiffs and the members of the Class, 
20  the Classโs claims can and will be most effectively managed by a class action.

20  participants even threatened violence against individuals taking pictures in public places and 
21  property owners painting over graffiti on their own buildings.   
22  225.  Even if the Cityโs conduct and policies were not discriminatory on the basis of 
23  political speech, the Cityโs policies and conduct were irrational and arbitrary.   
24  226.  For instance, the Cityโs policy of refusing to respond to 9-1-1 calls from the CHOP 
25  area, while continuing to respond to 9-1-1 calls and provide emergency services elsewhere in the 
 
27 
FIRST AMENDED CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT    LAW OFFICES 
CALFO EAKES LLP 
Case No. 2:20-cv-00983 TSZ - 63  1301 SECOND AVENUE, SUITE 2800

1  City, was irrational because any obstructions or dangers to providing services within CHOP were 
2  created and maintained by the Cityโs own policy of supporting and endorsing the actions of the 
3  CHOP participants.   
4  227.  Moreover, the policy was arbitrary because City continued to respond to 9-1-1 calls 
5  and provide emergency services outside of the CHOP area, including in similarly dangerous 
6  situations.  For example, while CHOP was still ongoing, the City provided emergency response 
7  services in the following dangerous situations, among many others: 
8  a.  In North Seattle on June 29, police reportedly responded to โ[a] 911 call with 
9  yelling in the background and a report of a man with a gun.โ8  Medics 
10  responded to the scene as well.   
11  b.  In Wallingford on June 24, Seattle Police Department officers responded to 
12  reports of a man in crisis and armed with a knife and took the suspect into 
13  custody.9 
14  c.  On June 24, the Seattle Fire Department responded to reports of a gas leak near 
15  the 5000 block of 14th Avenue NW.10   
16  d.  On June 22, the Seattle Fire Department responded to reports of toxic fumes 
17  in a building at the 10300 block of Meridian Ave N.11 
18  228.  Through the above-alleged conduct, the City has violated the Equal Protection 
19  Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.   
20  229.  The City did so pursuant to City policy as created and ratified by City policymakers, 
21  including Mayor Durkan.   
22  230.  Plaintiffs and the Class have been harmed by this denial of equal protection, 
23  including through loss of revenue, loss of property value, damages to property, and other damages.

3  VIII.  PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
4  WHEREFORE, Plaintiffs request the following relief: 
5  A.  Judgment in favor of Plaintiffs and against Defendant for actual damages in an 
6  amount to be proven at trial; 
7  B.  Prejudgment interest at the maximum rate allowed by law; 
8  C.  Plaintiffsโ costs of investigation, costs of suit, and reasonable attorneysโ fees; and  
9  D.  All such other and further monetary, injunctive, and declaratory relief as the Court
