1    Plaintiffs hereby allege as follows: 
2  I.  OVERVIEW 
3  1.  The  rights  of  free  speech  and  to  peaceably  assemble  are  enshrined  in  our 
4  constitutional tradition. Plaintiffs support free-speech rights and support the efforts of those like 
5  Black Lives Matter who, by exercising such rights, are bringing issues such as systemic racism 
6  and  unfair  violence  against  African  Americans  by  police  to  the  forefront  of  the  national 
7  consciousness. Specifically, Plaintiffs support the free speech rights of many of those who have 
8  gathered on Capitol Hill to form what has been called โCHAZ,โ standing for the โCapitol Hill 
9  Autonomous Zone,โ or โCHOPโ for โCapitol Hill Organized Protestโ or โCapitol Hill Occupying 
10  Protest.โ1   
11  2.  This lawsuit does not seek to undermine CHOP participantsโ message or present a 
12  counter-message.  Rather,  this  lawsuit  is  about  the  constitutional  and  other  legal  rights  of 
13  Plaintiffsโbusinesses, employees, and residents in and around CHOPโwhich have been overrun 
14  by  the  City  of  Seattleโs  unprecedented  decision  to  abandon  and  close  off  an  entire  city 
15  neighborhood, leaving it unchecked by the police, unserved by fire and emergency health services, 
16  and inaccessible to the public at large. The Cityโs decision has subjected businesses, employees, 
17  and residents of that neighborhood to extensive property damage, public safety dangers, and an 
18  inability to use and access their properties. 
19  3.  On June 8, 2020, the City of Seattle (โthe Cityโ) abruptly deserted the Seattle Police 
20  Departmentโs East Precinct on the corner of Twelfth Avenue and E. Pine Street in Seattleโs Capitol 
21  Hill neighborhood, leaving behind numerous barriers that had previously been used as a line 
22  between police and protesters. 
23 
24 
 
25 
1 This complaint primarily refers to the area as โCHOP,โ and the people who are participating in CHOP who are not 
businesses, employees, or residents of the area as โCHOP participants.โ 
 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT - 2    LAW OFFICES 
CALFO EAKES LLP 
  1301 SECOND AVENUE, SUITE 2800 
SEATTLE, WASHINGTON 98101 
TEL, (206) 407-2200   FAX, (206) 407-2224 
 

Case 2:20-cv-00983   Document 1   Filed 06/24/20   Page 3 of 56
 
1  4.  When the City abandoned the precinct and the nearby barriers, a number of 
2  individuals who had been in the area took control of the barriers and used them to block off streets 
3  in an area around the East Precinct.  
4  5.  In  the  days  and  weeks  after  the  City  abandoned  the  East  Precinct,  CHOP 
5  participants have occupied the public streets, sidewalks, and parks in the area at all hours of the 
6  day and night. Rather than seeking to restore order and protect the residents and property owners 
7  within CHOP, the City instead chose to actively endorse, enable, and participate in the occupation 
8  of CHOP.  
9  6.  The City has provided Cal Anderson Park, a public park located at the center of 
10  CHOP,  to CHOP for use  as the staging ground supporting CHOPโs occupation of the surrounding 
11  area. Supported by the City, countless CHOP participants now reside in the park at all times of day 
12  and night, having turned it into a tent city. At any given time, hundreds of CHOP participants are 
13  camped out in the park. Violence, vandalism, excessive noise, public drug use, and other crimes 
14  are rampant within the park.  
15  7.  The Cityโs conduct has resulted in CHOP being blocked off from public access. 
16  Among other conduct detailed below, the City recently provided the participants with concrete 
17  barriers to use to block the streets, which CHOP participants have indeed used to barricade the 
18  streets and create borders. These borders have, at times, been guarded by armed CHOP participants 
19  who oversee who can or cannot enter CHOP. As a result, the streets are barred to most all vehicular 
20  traffic, making it virtually impossible for residents and businesses to access their buildings, receive 
21  deliveries, and provide goods and services to the few customers willing to enter CHOP.  
22  8.  The Cityโs conduct has also resulted in the elimination of basic public safety within 
23  CHOP and nearby areas. For example, the City has enacted a policy under which police will not 
24  enter the CHOP area except during life-and-death emergencies, and, even in those situations, the 
25  response is, at best, muted and late. After a fatal shooting in the early morning of June 20, 2020, 
 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT - 3    LAW OFFICES 
CALFO EAKES LLP 
  1301 SECOND AVENUE, SUITE 2800 
SEATTLE, WASHINGTON 98101 
TEL, (206) 407-2200   FAX, (206) 407-2224 
 

Case 2:20-cv-00983   Document 1   Filed 06/24/20   Page 4 of 56
 
1  for example, officers did not even approach the area of the shooting until approximately 20 minutes 
2  after the shooting, and no professional medical response was available for at least 15 minutes. At 
3  other times, even during life-and-death emergencies, the police have acquiesced to demands from 
4  CHOP participants that they abandon the area. The City has acknowledged the serious safety issues 
5  it has created, in particular noting that there are โdangerous conditionsโ at night, but the City has 
6  nonetheless chosen to maintain its policy of providing resources and support to the CHOP 
7  occupiers.  
8  9.  The Cityโs conduct has enabled the widespread destruction and vandalism of 
9  private property. Graffiti is pervasive throughout CHOPโit is not only on barriers, streets, 
10  sidewalks, but also on nearly every private building within CHOP. Graffiti that is painted over 
11  almost immediately returns, and property owners have been told by CHOP participants that if they 
12  dare to paint over graffiti, their buildings will be more severely vandalized or even burned to the 
13  ground. The City has done nothing to prevent this conduct, but, instead, has actively endorsed and 
14  supported  the  ongoing  occupation  of  the  CHOP  area  and  the  destruction  of  property  that 
15  accompanies it. As a result, property owners and their tenants have not been able to fully use their 
16  properties. Property owners and tenants have, for instance, had to lock and barricade their garages 
17  and loading areas at risk of having CHOP participants entering and vandalizing them. 
18  10.  The property owners, businesses, and residents in the area suffer ever-increasing 
19  property damage and economic loss every day that CHOP exists in their neighborhood, all because 
20  of the Cityโs active support, encouragement, and endorsement of the occupation. In particular, 
21  Seattle Mayor Jenny Durkan has provided the CHOP participants with not just tangible resources 
22  but also a de facto stamp of approval. Her tweets, interviews, and other statements have made it 
23  clear that the City is fully aware of what is happening, has no plan or timeline for remedying the 
24  ongoing harm, and in fact views the occupation of Capitol Hill as something akin to a perpetual 
25  block party. 
 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT - 4    LAW OFFICES 
CALFO EAKES LLP 
  1301 SECOND AVENUE, SUITE 2800 
SEATTLE, WASHINGTON 98101 
TEL, (206) 407-2200   FAX, (206) 407-2224 
 

Case 2:20-cv-00983   Document 1   Filed 06/24/20   Page 5 of 56
 
1  11.  Plaintiffs and others have repeatedly pleaded with Mayor Durkan and others to 
2  cease enabling the destruction of their property and the imminent dangers posed to them and their 
3  neighborhood. But the City has not listened, or has not cared, and Plaintiffs have had to resort to 
4  litigation to make themselves heard. 
5  12.  Again,  this  case is  not  about  Plaintiffsโ  agreement  or  disagreement  with  the 
6  inspiration for CHOP, or the viewpoints expressed by the people occupying that area. Instead, it 
7  is about the Cityโs active, knowing endorsement and support of a destructive occupation of a 
8  neighborhood to the detriment of the well-being of those who live and work in that neighborhood. 
9  II.  PARTIES 
10  13.  Plaintiffs are residents, tenants, property owners, and small businesses in Seattleโs 
11  Capitol Hill neighborhood that have been harmed by CHOP. Without an injunction restraining the 
12  City from continuing its policies of supporting and enabling the occupation of the CHOP area, 
13  each of the Plaintiffs will continue to suffer irreparable harm, by, among other things, being subject 
14  to acts of violence, harassment, trespass and vandalism; denial of access to their property; loss of 
15  police protection and public services, including trash, medical, and fire services; loss of business 
16  revenue; loss of the use of public streets, sidewalks, and parks near or adjacent to their property, 
17  residence, or premises; reduction in property value; destruction of property; and other economic 
18  and non-economic injuries. 
19  14.  Plaintiff Hunters Capital LLC (โHunters Capitalโ) is a Washington limited liability 
20  company with its principal place of business in King County, Washington. Hunters Capital is a 
21  real-estate development, investment, and management company, headquartered near Cal Anderson 
22  Park in the Capitol Hill neighborhood with offices in the zone occupied by CHOP at 1620 
23  Broadway Seattle, Washington. Hunters Capital owns and manages a portfolio of commercial, 
24  multi-family residential, and mixed-use properties in the Capitol Hill neighborhood within and 
25  around CHOP, including 500 E. Pike Street, 1517 12th Avenue, 401 E. Pine Street, 1000 E. Pike

3  Hunters Capital has suffered, and continues to suffer, economic loss from CHOP. Additionally, its 
4  property has been damaged and its tenants and employees have been harassed.  
5  15.  Plaintiff SRJ Enterprises, Inc. d/b/a Car Tender (โCar Tenderโ) is a Washington

24  Capitol Hill neighborhood, located on the corner of 12th Avenue and Pine Street at 1605 12th 
25  Avenue, Seattle, Washington, directly across from the East Precinct and wholly within CHOP.

1  Customers cannot access Northwest Liquor and Wine because of CHOP and since the occupation 
2  began in early June, the companyโs sales have been down approximately 70%. 
3  18.  Sage  Physical  Therapy  PLLC  (โSage  Physical  Therapyโ)  is  a  Washington

24  Services owns or manages over 250,000 square feet of real estate in Capitol Hill, including

1  III.  JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
2  30.  This Court has subject-matter jurisdiction over this case under 28 U.S.C. ยง1331 
3  because this action presents federal questions and seeks to redress deprivations of rights under 
4  the United States Constitution pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983. 
5  31.  Venue is proper in this District under 28 U.S.C. ยง 1391(e)(1) because the events 
6  giving rise to these claims arose in the Western District of Washington. 
7  IV.  FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS 
8  A.  The Creation of CHOP 
9  32.  On June 8, 2020, with protests ongoing near the East Precinct, the City emptied the 
10  East Precinct of all weapons and valuables, and then abandoned it. 
11  33.  The City left behind at the precinct and in the surrounding areas large barriers that 
12  had been used in previous days to try to limit the movements of protesters. 
13  34.  Predictably, almost immediately after the SPD abandoned the precinct and the 
14  barriers, CHOP participants used the barriers to block off streets in the area and create a โno-copโ 
15  zone. Initially, the blocked-off area extended to all streets within one block from the precinct. 
16  35.  Without  any  police  presence,  the  CHOP  participants  organized  themselves, 
17  declared the area โFree Capitol Hill,โ and stationed guards by the barriers that the City had 
18  abandoned, thereby creating borders for the occupied area. The area later expanded, was referred 
19  to as CHAZ for several days, and eventually became known as CHOP. 
20  36.  CHOPโs unofficial boundaries stretch north to East Denny Way, east to 13th 
21  Avenue, south to East Pike Street, and west to Broadway. It encompasses the entirety of Cal 
22  Anderson Park and sixteen city blocks in all.

1  n.  Whether Plaintiffs and the Class are entitled to injunctive relief. 
2  155.  The claims of the Plaintiffs are typical of the members of the Class. All Plaintiffs 
3  reside in the Class and have been subject to the same course of conduct by the City. 
4  156.  The Plaintiffs will fairly and adequately represent the Class. Plaintiffs are all 
5  members of the Class and have there are no conflicts between Plaintiffs and other Class members. 
6  Plaintiffs are well-informed as to the nature of this case and the claims against the City and have

8  157.  The City has acted or refused to act on grounds that apply generally to all Plaintiffs 
9  and the Class such that injunctive relief is appropriate respecting the Class as a whole. 
10  158.  The issues that Class members have in common predominate over any individual 
11  issues. The City engaged in a common course of conduct giving rise to the harms suffered by 
12  Plaintiffs and the Class. A single, common policy is at issue in this case. Individual questions, if 
13  any, pale by comparison to the numerous common questions that dominate. The injuries sustained 
14  by the Class members flow, in each instance, from a common nucleus of operative facts. 
15  159.  A class action is superior to other available methods for the fair and efficient 
16  adjudication of this controversy because joinder of all class members is impracticable. The 
17  prosecution of separate actions by individual members of the Class would impose heavy burdens 
18  upon the courts and the City and would create a risk of inconsistent or varying adjudications of the 
19  questions of law and fact common to the Class. A class action would achieve substantial economies 
20  of time, effort, and expense, and would assure uniformity of decision as to persons similarly 
21  situated without sacrificing procedural fairness. Individual litigation of the legal and factual issues 
22  raised by the conduct of the City would increase delay and expense to all parties and to the court 
23  system. The class action device presents far fewer management difficulties and provides the 
24  benefits of a single, uniform adjudication, economies of scale and comprehensive supervision by 
25  a single court. Given the similar nature of the claims of the members of the Class and the uniform

Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 11   Filed 07/23/20   Page 2 of 21
 
1  LLC, a Washington limited liability company, 
on behalf of themselves and others similarly 
2  situated, 
 
3          Plaintiffs, 
 
4      vs. 
 
5  CITY OF SEATTLE, 
 
6          Defendant. 
 
7   
 
8    Under Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and 23, the City moves to dismiss plaintiffsโ 
9  Complaint for failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted and to deny class certification. 
10  I.  INTRODUCTION 
11  Plaintiffs seek to hold the City responsible for the acts of private parties in and around the 
12  Capitol Hill Organized Protest (โCHOPโ).1 However, the City is not liable for those private acts and 
13  the complaint fails to state a claim as a matter of law. The City took measured, appropriate steps to 
14  rapidly unfolding events in responding to the CHOP. As has been widely reported, the City supported 
15  the exercise of First Amendment rights by peaceful protesters in public streets and a park in the 
16  Capitol Hill neighborhood of Seattle following the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis.2 Plaintiffs 
17  expressly โsupport the free-speech rights of many of those who gathered on Capitol Hillโ but are 
18  unclear about whose free-speech rights they do not support.  Complaint at ยถ1. As the amended 
19 
 
1 The CHOP has also been referred to as the Capitol Hill Occupied Protest and the Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone 
20 
(โCHAZโ). 
2 โThe protections afforded by the First Amendment are nowhere stronger than in streets and parks, both categorized for 
21  First Amendment purposes as traditional public fora. In such fora, the government's right โto limit expressive activity [is] 
sharply circumscribed.โ Perry Educ. Ass'n, 460 U.S. at 45, 103 S.Ct. 948. Among traditional public fora, public parks โฆ 
are especially important locales for communication among the citizenry, as they have immemorially been held in trust for 
22 
the use of the public and, time out of mind, have been used for purposes of assembly, communicating thoughts between 
citizens, and discussing public questions.โ Berger v. City of Seattle, 569 F.3d 1029, 1035โ36 (9th Cir. 2009) (some 
23  citations, quotations, and footnotes omitted). 
 
DEFENDANTโS MOTION TO DISMISS AND DENY CLASS  Peter S. Holmes 
Seattle City Attorney 
CERTIFICATION - 2 
701 5th Avenue, Suite 2050 
2:20-CV-00983  Seattle, WA 98104-7095 
 
(206) 684-8200
 
 
 

Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 11   Filed 07/23/20   Page 3 of 21
 
1  complaint acknowledges, when opportunistic criminal and other activity in and around the CHOP 
2  overshadowed important free speech activity, the City cleared the CHOP.  
3  Plaintiffs allege they were deprived of their rights to due process and equal protection and that 
4  they suffered takings of their property because the City did not act sooner to clear the CHOP. They 
5  bring federal claims under 42 USC ยง1983. However, plaintiffs fail to state any claims upon which 
6  relief may be granted.  
7  Governments are not required to prevent third-party conduct, including criminal conduct, 
8  absent rare exceptions to the rule not presented here. Although they attempt to blame the City for 
9  private acts, the conduct that the plaintiffs complain of is that of private parties who plaintiffs have 
10  not named in this suit. Their complaint also fails to comply with requirements for a damages class 
11  under FRCP 23. This Court should dismiss plaintiffsโ complaint with prejudice. If the Court does not 
12  dismiss the Complaint outright, it should deny class certification.    
13  II.  FACTS 
14  As a purported class, plaintiffs allege that the City violated their civil rights by leaving the 
15  East Precinct building and not clearing the CHOP sooner. Complaint at ยถยถ3, 35-38.3 As required in a 
16  Rule 12(b)(6) motion, all well-pled factual allegations in the Complaint are treated as true for 
17  purposes of this motion.  They note that City barriers were used by protesters to block City streets 
18  and vehicular access to residences and buildings. Id. at ยถยถ4, 7. They allege that the City is responsible 
19  for the acts of those they allege are โCHOP participantsโ because the City โendorse[d], enable[d], and 
20 
21 
 
3 Plaintiffs suggest that the City cleared the CHOP in response to a threatened TRO motion from Plaintiffs. Although it 
22 
has no bearing on the motion before the Court, the City feels compelled to note that plaintiffs are mistaken. The City made 
its decision to clear the CHOP based on events in the CHOP, not this lawsuit. That the clearing of the CHOP was a success 
23  speaks to the Cityโs careful approach and operational planning and provides no support for the contention that there was 
undue delay on the Cityโs part.  
DEFENDANTโS MOTION TO DISMISS AND DENY CLASS  Peter S. Holmes 
Seattle City Attorney 
CERTIFICATION - 3 
701 5th Avenue, Suite 2050 
2:20-CV-00983  Seattle, WA 98104-7095 
 
(206) 684-8200
 
 
 

Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 11   Filed 07/23/20   Page 4 of 21
 
1  participate[d] in the occupation of CHOP.โ E.g., id. at ยถ5.4  Generally, plaintiffs complain that they 
2  were harmed by the criminal and other acts of CHOP participants, not City actors. Id. ยถยถ8-9, 40-48, 
3  51-53. 
4  Plaintiffs complain that the Cityโs non-enforcement of laws led to pervasive crimes of 
5  vandalism by non-City actors. Id. at ยถ9. They allege that the Cityโs support for the Black Lives Matter 
6  movement and attempts to find a peaceful resolution to the CHOP amounts to an endorsement of 
7  criminal and other activity. Id. at ยถ10.  
8  As a group, plaintiffs complain of a variety of harm, including graffiti, different provision of 
9  emergency services inside the CHOP than outside it, and loss of vehicular access to their property 
10  stemming from CHOP participantsโ use of barriers.  They complain that the City did not engage in 
11  regular policing within CHOP and declined to enforce criminal laws. Id. at ยถ174, 219. They allege 
12  the  City  โenabledโ  CHOP  participants  to  block  vehicular  access  and  physically  aided  CHOP 
13  participants by leaving barriers in the area, providing more barriers, and providing portable toilets 
14  and other equipment. ยถยถ177, 179. They further contend that the City โeffectively authorizedโ the 
15  actions of CHOP participants by allowing CHOP to exist for weeks. Id. at ยถ181.  
16  Individual members of the purported class make other complaints, including that the โpolice 
17  refused to protectโฆ property.โ Id. at ยถ91. They also allege lost revenue, lost access, feeling unsafe, 
18  decreased property values, physical property damage, reduced rents, criminal activity of CHOP 
19  participants, non-response to 911 calls, inability to receive deliveries, and harassment by CHOP 
20  participants. Id. at ยถยถ85, 91, 99, 104-106, 135, 143, 149.   
21   
22 
 
4 Although the City uses the term โCHOP participantsโ to match up with the amended complaint here and elsewhere, it 
23  does not agree that it is appropriate to lump the many peaceful protesters who participated or visited the CHOP into a 
group with those committing crimes and the other acts identified in the amended complaint.  
DEFENDANTโS MOTION TO DISMISS AND DENY CLASS  Peter S. Holmes 
Seattle City Attorney 
CERTIFICATION - 4 
701 5th Avenue, Suite 2050 
2:20-CV-00983  Seattle, WA 98104-7095 
 
(206) 684-8200
 
 
 

Case 2:20-cv-00983-TSZ   Document 11   Filed 07/23/20   Page 5 of 21
 
1  III.  ARGUMENT AND AUTHORITIES 
2  A.  Motion to Dismiss Standard 
3  Dismissal under Rule 12(b)(6) requires a court to determine โwhether the complaint's factual 
4  allegations, together with all reasonable inferences, state a plausible claim for relief.โ Cafasso, U.S. 
5  ex rel. v. Gen. Dynamics C4 Sys. Inc., 637 F.3d 1047, 1054 (9th Cir. 2011) (citing Ashcroft v. 
6  Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662, 677-78, 129 S.Ct. 1937, 1949โ50 (2009)). โA claim has facial plausibility when 
7  the plaintiff pleads factual content that allows the court to draw the reasonable inference that the 
8  defendant is liable for the misconduct alleged.โ Iqbal, 556 U.S. at 678, 129 S.Ct. at 1949 (citation 
9  omitted). When determining the sufficiency of a claim, a court must โaccept factual allegations in the

6  To maintain a claim under ยง1983, a Plaintiff must show that (1) the conduct complained of

13  Cir. 2010)(internal quotation marks and citations omitted ). It exists to โavoid[ ] imposing on the 
14  State,  its  agencies  or  officials,  responsibility  for  conduct  for  which  they  cannot  fairly  be

1  Although unclear from the Amended Complaint, it is possible plaintiffs make a novel โclass 
2  of oneโ argument as to each purported class member. See Engquist v. Oregon Department of 
3  Agriculture, 553  U.S.  591,  128  S.Ct.  2146,  170  L.Ed.2d  975  (2008).  Such  claims  require 
4  discriminatory intent and cannot be supported by an alleged failure to take a discretionary act alone. 
5  See Engquist, 553 U.S. at 601-09, 128 S.Ct. at 2152-2157; Hanes v. Zurick, 578 F.3d 491, 496 (7th 
6  Cir. 2009) (An โofficer motivated by malice alone is not exercising discretion and is not weighing the 
7  factors relevant to the officer's duties to the public.โ); Le Fay v. Le Fay, 1:13-CV-1362 AWI MJS, 
8  2015 WL 106262, at *7 (E.D. Cal. Jan. 7, 2015), aff'd sub nom. LeFay v. LeFay, 673 Fed. Appx. 722 
9  (9th Cir. 2016) (malice required to support class of one theory in case involving class of one equal 
10  protection theory based on discretionary law enforcement decision). Critically, plaintiffs do not allege 
11  that the City was motived by malice and therefore took discriminatory action against them. Rather, 
12  they allege that the City failed to stop private actors from conduct which the plaintiffs (often 
13  understandably) disliked. Plaintiffsโ complaint fails to allege the basic factual elements required to 
14  support an equal protection claim. The courtโs analysis need go no further than this to determine that 
15  their equal protection claim fails.  
16  2.  To  the  extent  the  Plaintiffs  make  a  First  Amendment  claim  under  the  Equal 
Protection clause, it fails because they do not allege (1) the City took retaliatory 
17  action against them because of their speech (2) that would have chilled a person of 
ordinary firmness from participating in First Amendment speech or (3) that they 
18  were injured by government retaliation. 
 
19  Government action that suppresses protected speech in a discriminatory manner may violate 
20  both the First Amendment and the Equal Protection Clause. R.A.V. v. City of St. Paul, 505 U.S. 377, 
21  384 n. 4, 112 S.Ct. 2538, 120 L.Ed.2d 305 (1992) (noting that the Supreme Court โhas occasionally 
22 
 
23  individuals whom they suspected might hold viewpoints contrary to their own[.]โ  Complaint at ยถ224 (emphasis added).  
This is not enough to establish governmental retaliation based on an expressed viewpoint.

1  fused  the  First  Amendment  into  the  Equal  Protection  Clause  in  this  fashion,  but  ...  with  the 
2  acknowledgment ... that the First Amendment underlies its analysis.โ). Where plaintiffs allege 
3  violations of the Equal Protection Clause relating  to  expressive conduct,  courts analyze those 
4  arguments using the framework applicable to alleged content or viewpoint discrimination under the 
5  First Amendment. Dariano v. Morgan Hill Unified Sch. Dist., 767 F.3d 764, 779โ80 (9th Cir. 2014). 
6  To demonstrate a First Amendment violation, a plaintiff must (1)  provide evidence  of 
7  retaliatory governmental action motivated by an intention to interfere with First Amendment rights; 
8  (2) that defendantโs conduct โwould chill or silence a person of ordinary firmness from future First 
9  Amendment activity,โ Mendocino Envtl. Ctr. v. Mendocino Cty., 192 F.3d 1283, 1300 (9th Cir. 1999) 
10  (citation omitted) and (3) that but for the governmentโs retaliatory acts an injury to the plaintiff would 
11  not have occurred. Lacey v. Maricopa Cty., 693 F.3d 896, 917 (9th Cir. 2012). In the First Amendment 
12  context, there is no right to a response or any particular action when a citizen petitions the government 
13  for redress of a grievance, including filing a police report.  See, e.g.. Mancini v. City of Cloverdale 
14  Police Dep't, 15-CV-02804-JSC, 2015 WL 4512274, at *6 (N.D. Cal. July 24, 2015); Doe v. County 
15  of San Mateo, 2009 WL 735149 at *6 (N.D. Cal. March 19, 2009).  
16    Here, plaintiffs allege no facts that the Cityโs response to the CHOP was motivated by a desire 
17  to suppress plaintiffsโ speech. They do not identify what speech plaintiffs engaged in or even desired 
18  to engage in, when the City heard it, nor how the City retaliated against it. The allegedly retaliatory 
19  acts they complainโthreats of violence, for exampleโare not City actions, but that of private actors. 
20  In short, plaintiffsโ complaint satisfies none of the elements of a First Amendment claim, and their 
21  First Amendment claim under the Equal Protection clause is properly dismissed as a matter of law.

1  G.  Class certification is unavailable because plaintiffs complain of distinct harms occurring 
at different times and differing damages  
2   
FRCP 23(c)(1)(A) addresses the timing of a district court's class certification determination, 
3 
and states: โTime to Issue: At an early practicable time after a person sues or is sued as a class 
4 
representative, the court must determine by order whether to certify the action as a class action.โ 
5 
FRCP 23(c)(1)(A). Preemptive motions by the defense to deny class certification are properly 
6 
considered by the trial court. Vinole v. Countrywide Home Loans, Inc., 571 F.3d 935, 940 (9th Cir. 
7 
2009). Whether to permit discovery prior to considering a motion to deny certification is within the 
8 
discretion of the trial court, and discovery is properly denied where plaintiffs do not make a prima 
9 
facie showing  of  Rule  23's  prerequisites  or  that  discovery  measures  were  โlikely  to  produce 
10 
persuasive information substantiating the class action allegations.โ Doninger v. Pac. Nw. Bell, 
11 
Inc., 564 F.2d 1304, 1313 (9th Cir. 1977). 
12 
Class certification is not appropriate in civil rights cases involving varied incidents that 
13 
produced differing harms allegedly caused by third parties and governments. Plaintiffs in such cases 
14 
cannot satisfy Rule 23(a)(2)โs commonality requirement. In a recent, and directly comparable, 
15 
Northern District of California case, the court denied class certification in a case involving a โcreated 
16 
dangerโ theory where police officers were alleged to have directed plaintiffs into a dangerous crowd. 
17 
Hernandez v. City of San Jose, 16-CV-03957-LHK, 2019 WL 4450930, at *15 (N.D. Cal. Sept. 17, 
18 
2019). The court noted that causation โdoomedโ plaintiffsโ class certification motion. Id. Each alleged 
19 
incident would require a causation analysis, and because the incidents involved โthird-party attackersโ 
20 
there were unique proximate cause arguments as to each plaintiff: each would be required to show 
21 
that they would not have been injured by private parties but for the governmental action. Id. The same 
22 
analysis holds true here, and it warrants denial of class certification on this ground alone. 
23

1  The Hernandez court also noted that damages issues in cases like this one pose an 
2  insurmountable predominance problem under Rule 23(b)(3). Id. (citing and quoting Lambert v. 
3  Nutraceutical Corp., 870 F.3d 1170, 1182 (9th Cir. 2017), rev'd and remanded on other grounds, 
4  139 S. Ct. 710 (2019)(โ[a] Rule 23(b)(3) plaintiff must show a class wide method for damages 
5  calculations as a part of the assessment of whether common questions predominate over individual 
6  questions.โ)). Hernandez noted that each plaintiff was alleging different injuries that would not be 
7  susceptible to calculation using a damages model, as required by Rule 23. In cases like Hernandez 
8  and this one โ[q]uestions of individual damage calculations will inevitably overwhelm questions 
9  common to the class.โ Comcast Corp. v. Behrend, 569 U.S. 27, 34, 133 S. Ct. 1426, 1433, 185 L. 
10  Ed. 2d 515 (2013) (cited and quoted in Hernandez at *17). 
11  As in Hernandez, for multiple reasons, there is no class here that can be properly certified. 
12  The City therefore respectfully requests the Court deny class certification, in the event that the 
13  Cityโs Rule 12 motion is not granted in full.  
14  IV.  CONCLUSION  
15  Plaintiffs  complain  of  private  action,  not  discriminatory  governmental  action.  Their 
16  allegations that the City knew of ongoing criminal and other activity and failed to stop it cannot 
17  support their due process and equal protection claims. Similarly, their allegation that property access 
18  was temporarily impaired (but never eliminated) by private parties cannot establish a viable takings 
19  claim. Similarly, their purported class cannot satisfy basic Rule 23 requirements.  
20  Pursuant to Rule 12, because Plaintiffs fail to state a claim upon which relief can be granted, 
21  the City requests plaintiffsโ complaint be dismissed with prejudice. In the alternative, the City requests
